I have enjoyed under the wing of my dear & virtuous
mother. when I call to mind her sufferings, & ours for
many years, what cause have I of deep consideration
of the goodness of God towards us all which has not deprived
us of our sole comfort, & stay. by taking away my dear
Mother, in whose life was our support with whom we were all preser
-ved from death & Ruin. in Ireland; at Kirklington; at
Chester, & in all places; ever since my Fathers death; in
all these sad times. in the opposition of friends, the fall of the
Church & state. when her Jointure in England being but 300l
per Annum at best, fell under 50l a year & when the Scots devoured
all her Patrimony, eating up her own, &, children's Provisions,
even then did our gracious Lord remember mercy in the midst
of Judgement. and caused her house at.
117
Hipswell to be a Zoar, a sanctuary for us all; And out of
that little Estate (then, not being the 10th part of the whole).
she relieved my brother George, which had a particular Es
Estate of his own, as Heir (though under sequestration)
with the some of 500l And since my fathers death, she
hath expended upon her 3 younger Children's main
-tenance out of her own at Hipswell the some of
1500l in our education & maintenance. as she has
declared by her own relation before witnesses.

None of us ever having received any thing out of
that part of my fathers Estate, of Kirklington for
the same as was appointed by my Fathers, last will
& testament. Therefore will I give glory to our God
on high which still has preserved this dear & tender
Mother. there by testifying his miraculous favours
to the desolate widow, & Children, in all times of
desertion & troubles. And being mindful of his
Servant my father, in the blessing poured down upon
his Family. The Lord our God make us ever grateful
and thankful to his gracious, Majesty for Ever. Amen.

My Cosen mary Yorke, was married to Mr John York
at her fathers house, my uncle nortons on the Greene
in Richmond April the 12th 1651.

My brother Christopher Wandesforde, married
Sir John Lowthers Daughter Mrs Eleanor the Eldest
Daughter, at Sir Johns House (Lowther in Westmo-
oreland) the 30th of September 1651.

div.head: The Marriage of Alice Wandesforde December 15 1651.
div.p:
After many troubles & afflictions, under which it
pleased God to Exercise my mother, & self in, since the death
of my father, she was desirous to see me comfortably
settled in the Estate of Marriage. in which she hoped to recea
-ve some satisfaction; finding Age. & weakness, to seize
more each year. which added a spur to her desires, for the
future well being of her Children according to every one
of their capacities.

As to my self; I was exceedingly satisfied in that happy
& free condition; wherein I enjoyed in that time with delight abundantly
in the Service of my god & the obedience I owed to such an exce
-lent Parent. in whose Enjoyment I accounted my days
spent with great content and comfort; the only fears which
possessed me, was least I should be deprived of that great
blessing I had in her life. nor could I with out much reluc-
-tancy draw my thoughts to the change of my single life,
knowing to much of the cares of this world sufficiently
with out the addition of such, incident to the married. Estate.

As to the fortune left by my father; it was fair, & more
then Competent, so that I needed not fear (by Gods blessing
to have bin troublesome to my friends, but to be rather in a
condition to assist them, it need had required.

Especially more, in regard. that I was confident of what
my dear mother could doe for me (living,) & at her death.
So that to show my dear affection towards my brother
George. in the time of his straights. for his better help in
his Estate; being sore burdened with Debts Annuities &c
I was willing to transfer, 500l of my English portion
to be received out of Ireland. which would have eased that
of kirklington. But since his death. when my 2d
Brother came heir. there was not that cause to continue
119
The same; by reason that both the sequestration was taken
of, & the wardship money of his brother denied to be paid to Sir
Edward Osbornes Excecutor & that he was better by 200l
a year in his Estate, with many other considerable ar
-guments arising towards my mother & my self;
for there was such unhandsome dealings to us not to
say (dishonest), since my brothers marriage. as could neither
induce her, or my self, to part with our Estates with
out security.

But I shall be silent in these things, which afforded us
too much troubles. & sorrows. wishing rather to cover
all things of the nature of disputes betwixt such near
relations.

And with all my youngest Brother John. being fallen into
a grievous distemper, through grief, upon harsh Dealing
after the marriage of my brother Christ. who by ill counsel
given him; detained, his right of Annuity of 100l per Annum
(to his great prejudice) & John was likely thereby to leave
both that 100l in England. with his whole fortune (then desend
ed upon John, by his brother George his death) of 6000l out of the
Irish Estate. to my brother Christopher.

Weighing all these reasons, together; & that I had no
maintenance from Kirklington as I ought to have
had, by my fathers will, but was willing to forego that to
my uncle will.m wandesforde towards the payment of Debts
I had no reason; from all these considerations to lose
the payment of the said 500l out of kirklington.

Yet I doe believe from hence proceeded much displeasure
that I would not consent to wrong my Self of the whole.
in so much that after the business of sequestration was
cleared he desisted the acting any thing in my behalf

Nevertheless, such was my dear mothers affection to the
Family, for its preservation; that she harkened to the pro-
posall made for Mr Thorntons Marriage: Albeit there
-in she disobliged some Persons of very good worth & quality
which had solicited her earnestly in my behalf, & such
as were of large & considerable Estates. of her neighbours
about her. And after the first & second view betwixt us
she closed so far with him that she was willing he should
proceed in his suite. & that cordially, if I should see cause, to Accept

For my own particular, I was not hasty to change my
free estate, with out much consideration, both as to my
present & future; the first inclining me rather to continue
so still; wherein none could be more satisfied.

The second would contract much more trouble, twisted
inseparably with those comforts God gave in that Estate.
Yet might I be hopeful to serve God in those duties in-
-combant on a, Wife, A mother, a mistress, & governess
in a Family. And if it pleased God so to dispose of me
in marriage making me a more public instrument of
good to those several relations. I thought it rather duty
in me to accept my friends desires for a joint benefit, then
my own single retired content, so that Almighty God
might receive the Glory of my change, & I more capacita-
ted to serve him in this Generation. in what he thus called
me unto.

Therefore it highly concerned me to enter into this great
-est Change of my life with abundance of fear & caution.
not lightly, nor unadvisedly, nor as, I may take my
God to witness that knows the secret of hearts; I did it not
to fulfil the lusts of the flesh. but in chastity, & singleness
of heart, as marrying in the Lord.

And to that end, that I might have a blessing upon
me, in all my undertakings. I poured out my petitions
before the God of my Life. to direct; strengthen, lead
& counsel me what to doe in this concern, which so
much tended to my future comfort or discomfort.

And to order my ways aright, so that if he saw in his
wisdom that the married estate was the best for me that he
would please to direct me in it. & incline my heart
towards it; but if otherwise it were best for me to be,
that I might still continue in the same. but still referring
my will to his. And also to order my change, that he so
would in mercy give me such a one, to be my husband
as might be an holy good & pious Christian. und-
-erstanding, wise & affectionate. that we might live in his
fear & favour. praying him to give unto me suitable
graces & qualifications, which should fit me for that
calling. & this for our Saviours Sake I humbly begged
in Jesus Christ our Lord Amen.

After which petitions to my God. I was the more inclined to
accept of this proposition, of my friends. finding also
that the Gentleman seemed to be a very godly sober &
discreet Person. free from all manner of vice, & of a
good conversation. this was the greatest incouragement
to me. when I considered the general decay of true
Religion, in profession & practice. Especially in the Gentry
& with men of quality; too many, being given to a sad
course of life, through debauchery. made me more
cautious in choosing, & fearing to meet with such as-
neither knew God, nor cared for their souls, to pre
-serve themselves in a holy course of life & conversation.
Nor could I ever have enjoyed comfort in this world to
have bin matched with the greatest Estates.

Or fortunes, had I wanted that first, & principal qua-
lification in a husband, which is to be regarded above all
the satisfaction this world can afford.

I cannot deny that his Estate which was then favourably given
into my Mother, was the least in value which had bin offered
yet did my Mother hope, to find a handsome competency
with out much charge as was represented to her, only
the want of a house which he must build, his brother & sister
being provided for by his mother that would clear his
Estate. which was given in to be 600l per annum.

This was very well; considering the addition of my
Fathers Portion given me by his will, & deeds, namely
1500l out of England, at Kirklington; and 1000l to be
paid out of his Irish Estate of Edough. which would be
an addition to increase Mr Thorntons Revenues.
Also my dear mother was willing to give me what
assistance she could out of her love & affection.

This treaty of marriage with Mr Thornton, was very
earnestly pursued by himself & friends, & as dis-
creetly managed by my dear mother, as she could
for she was in a manner left alone, by all our relations
Especially. after my brothers death, in regard that self
interest too far prevailed, for those to hinder my
disposal to any Person, by the
which they would be deprived
of their sinister expectations of my fortune.

But through Gods blessing this treaty was brought
to a period, to the satisfaction of each party, & with a
general consent, And The Articles of marriage drawn
up by Mr Thornton, for the right settlement of all things
concluded upon betwixt my dear Mother in my beha
lfe, & him self, were both just & honest. don by him.

The Articles of Agreement were according to the
President of his Fathers towards his mother. Vidz.
That All his Estate, should be passed by fine & reco
-very to enable him to entail the same upon his Issue
by me, male or female.

That his Lordship of Easte Newton then valued
at the yearly rent of 250l should be Estated on
me for A Jointure. & after the decease of the longer
liver of us two, to descend upon his sons & their
issue successively. for want of such heirs male to his
heirs females by me. &c. with out impeachment of
any manner of waste.

That Laistrop valued at the yearly rent of 160l
after the decease of his mother, married to Mr Gate
& then her Jointure. was Settled on Mr Thornton for
his life, after his decease upon his heirs male &
for default of such issue, to his daughters by me.

As for his Land at Cottingham. Richmond, called
Burne Parke the inheritance Estated as the other of L.
After a long lease made for the Provision of his
younger children's Portions & Maintenance, paid out
of it. The value wast accounted 100l Per Annum.

As for the security of my Portion he was to Reieave
the sum of 1500l out of Kirklington which he might
dispose of for himself & his own use. Being secured to me
And for the 1000l payable out of Ireland. he gave
bond to my mother to purchase Land of inheritance
for me during my Life, & for my Children at my
decease.

And with all my mother was willing to give us our Table
with all our Family for 3 years. these were the terms
betwixt them.

After which agreements Articles & writings done, there
followed a pretty space, ere his Mother had passed a
fine with him, in regard that his Father in Law, would not
join in the fine. & my Mothers counsel did not approve
of it to be legal for security with out it. but Mr Thorton
did faithfully engaged to doe the same legally &
pass the fine after his death.

but in the interim
I was left in an uncertainty for the
security of a Jointure in case of his death before me, &
when my Portion was disposed of by him, could have
no benefit thereby. so that my Mother could proceed no
further, least any ill consequent might follow, but
wholly this business was Left to my own choice, what
I would doe in this case. she being loath as upon her
own account, to under go such a concern in which
there was such a hazard. wherein she was not to be blamed,
butt Mr Thornton was very much troubled upon this un-
just denial of his Father in Law. by which he was likely
to have undone his desires. fell into much sadness &
discontent, which perhaps might hasten his Sickness that
he fell into, on his going from hipwell.

his Ague began in the way, to his mothers when finding
himself not able to go through. came back to Hipwell
falling exceeding ill into a fever, But upon the advice
of Dr wittie. he was let blood, & had all means used for
his recovery. but was brought dangerously ill. at the last
it pleased God that he recovered beyond all expectation.
And upon his recovery, I was willing to rely upon his
promise to my Mother, & his infinite expressions to my self I
rested upon Providence in the fulfilling of his desire. in
so much that about the December following proceeded our marriage
this is the true relation of this grand concern of my life, which
I have bin the more tedious in, because I would leave to
Posterity the Right understanding of that concern.

Alice Wandesforde the Daughter of Christopher
Wandesford Esquire late Lord Deputy of Ireland, was
married to william Thornton Esquire, of Easte Nuton.
at my Mothers house in Hipswell. by Mr Siddall
December the 15th 1651.

Mr Siddall made a most Pious & profitable exhortati
-on to us, showing our duties, & teaching us the fear of
the Lord in this our new Estate of life, with many Zealous
prayers for us. My dear & hon.red Mother gave me
in marriage, in the Presence of my owne brother John
Wand. my uncle Norton. My uncle Darley (Frances
my cozen Dodsworth of wattlosse. George Lightfoote
& dafeny. Robert webster. Martha Richison. Ralfe Janson
Robert Loftus the Ellder.

div.head:
A Relation of the Remarkable passages of my Life
since my Marriage beginning from the 15th of December. 1651.
1651.
div.p:
After my Marriage it was my duty to humble my
soul in prayer & supplication to the God of all the Earth
who had guided me in all my youth & Virgin Estate
to live in his fear & service. & direiting me to choose
a Godly & religious husband with whom I might through
his blessing spend the rest of my days. & to this purpose
I poured out my humble petitions & requests with hearty
thanks & praise for all my deliverances both spiritual
& temporal ever since I was borne to that Present hour
beseeching him, that as he in abundant mercy had heard
my unworthy requests in the beginning of this treaty. so
he would now Multiply his free grace & loving kind
-nesse to me his vile creature giving both to my Husband
and myself all those graces & spiritual comforts we
stood in need of in this our Marriage. that we might be marred
to him as verily as to Each other. & that we might behave
126
our selves as becometh the members of Christ to each other in
this band of wedlock, being instruments of each others salvat
tion, & if it were the divine pleasure to give us the comfort of
Children, they might be heirs of the Kingdom of heaven
when he should call them; & in this life instruments of build
ing up his Church, & the raising up of my husbands family
but this temporal blessing as all others of that nature with sub-
-servency to his wisdom, & good pleasure. that if he saw it
good we might not want a comfortable being in this world
nor want any thing with out the
which we could not serve him
comfortably. all which things I Craved with what so ever else he saw fit
to give us for the Lord Jesus his sake. Amen.

div.head:
A deliverance from death that day on which I was
married. December 15th 1651.
div.p:
That very day on which I was married; having bin in healh
[word] SiC ??? i.e., health.
& strength for many years before; I fell suddenly so ill
& sick, after 2 a clock in the afternoon. (that I thought).
& all that saw me) did believe it would have bin my last
night being surprised with a violent pain in my head, &
stomach causing a great vomiting & sickness, at my ???
which lasted 8 hours, before I had any intermission. but
blessed be the Lord our God, the father of mercies. which had
compassion on me & by the means that was used I was stre-
ngthened wonderfully beyond expectation being pretty
well about 10 a clock at night. My dear husband
with my Mother was exceeding tender over me which was a
great comfort to my Spirits. What the cause of this fit
was I could not conjecture. save that I might have brought
it upon me by cold taken the Night before when I sat
up late in preparing for the next day & washing my feet
at that time of the year, which my mother did believe was the
cause of that dangerous fit the next day.

But however it was, or from what cause it proceeded
I received a great mercy in my preservation from God
& shall ever acknowledge the same in humble gratitude
for his infinite loving kindness for ever.

I looked upon this first beginning of my new condition
to be a little discouragement. although god was able
to turn all things for the best, & to my good, that I
might not build too much hopes of happiness in things
of this world nor in the comforts of a loving husband
whom God had given me. but set my desires more up
on the love of my Lord & God.

div.head:
Meditations upon my deliverance of my first
Child & of the great sickness followed for 3 quarters of a year
August 6th 1652 lasted till May: 12 53.
div.p:
About seven weeks after I married. it pleased
God to give me the blessing of conception. the first
quarter I was exceeding sickly in breeding, till I
was with quick child. After which I was very strong
& healthy I bless God. only much hotter then formerly
as is usual in such cases from a natural cause.
in so much that my nose bled much when I was about
half gon by reason of the increase of heat.

Mr Thornton had a desire that I should visit his friends
in which I freely joined. his mother living about 50 miles
from Hipswell, & all at Newton, And Buttercrambe
In my passage thither I sweat exceedingly, & was
much inclining to be feverish, wanting not 8 weeks
of my time. so that Dr wittie said that I should go near to fall
into a fever, or some desperate sickness, If I did not
cool my blood, by taking some away. & if I had stayed
but 2 days longer, I had followed his advice.

In his return home from Newton his own Estate, I was
carried over Hambleton towards Sir will.m Akoughs house
where I passed down on foot a very high hill, betwixt
hud hill & whitsonclife, which is above a mile steep down
& indeed so bad, that I could not scarce tread the narrow steps
which was exceeding bad for me in that condition, & sore to in-
-dure the way so strait & none to lead me but my maid,
which could scarce make shift to get down her self. All our
company being gon down before, each step did very much
strain me being so big with child. nor could I have got down
if I had not then bin in my full strength & nimble on foot.

But I bless God I got down safe at last though much tired
& hot & weary, finding my self not well, but troubled with
pains after my walk: Mr Thornton would not have
brought me that way if he had known it so dangerous. & I
was a stranger in that place. but he was advised by some to
go that way before we came down the hill.

This was the first occasion which brought me a great deal of
Misery & killed my sweet infant in my womb. For I contineu
-ued in all pain by fits upon this journey. & with in a fortnight
fell into a desperate fever at Hipswell. upon which my old Dr
Mr Mahum was called. but could doe little towards the cure.
because of being with child. I was willing to be ordered by him but
said I found it absolutely necessary to be let blood if they
would save my life. but I was freely willing to resign my
will to Gods, if he saw fit for me, to spare my life yet to live
with my husband. but still with subservience to my heavenly father

Nor was I wanting to supplicate my God for direction what to
doe either for life or death. I had very often & frequent
impulsions to desire the later before the former finding no true
Joy in this Life. but I confess also that which moved me to use all
means for my Recovery in regard of the great Sorrow of my
129
Dear & Aged Mother, & my dear husband, took
for me, far exceeding my deserts made me more willing
to save my Life for them, & that I might render praises
to my God in the land of the living.

But truly I found my ??? still did cleave so much
to my Maker, that I never found my self more desirous of
a change. to be delivered from this wicked world & body
of sin & death, desiring to be dissolved & to be with Christ

Therefore endured I all the Rigour, & extremity of my
sickness, with such a share of Patience, as my God gave me.
As for my friends they were so much concerned for me
that upon the importunity of my husband, although I
was brought indeed very weak & desperately ill about,
11th day of my sickness. I did let him send for Dr wittie
if it were not too late.

The Dr came Post the next day. when he found me very
weak, & durst not, let me blood that night. but gave me
cordials & till the next day, & if I got but one hours
rest that night he would doe it the morning following. that night
the two Drs had a dispute about the letting me blood. Mr Mahum
was against it & Dr wittie for it. but I soon decided
that dispute & told them if they would save my life
I must bleed. so the next day I had 6 or 7 ounces taken which
was turned very bad by my sickness. but I found a
change immediately in my sight which was exceeding dime
before, & then I see as well as ever clearly. & my strength
began a little to return; these things I relate that I may
set forth the mercy of my ever gracious God, who had blessed
the means in such manner. who can sufficiently Extol
his Majesty for his boundless mercies to me his weak Creature
[word] SiC ??? i.e., creature.
For from that time I was better & he had hopes of my Life

The doctor stayed with me 7 days, during my sickness, my
130
Poor infant with in me was greatly forced with violent
Motions perpetually, till it grew so weak that it had left
stirring, & about the 27th of August, I found myself in
great pains as it were the colic. after which I began to be
in travail. And about the next day at night I was de-
-livered of a goodly daughter; who lived not so long as
that we could get a minister to baptise it though we
presently sent for one.

This my sweet babe & first Child departed this life half an
hour after its birth. being received, I hope into the Arms
of him that gave it. she was buried that night being friday the
27th of August. 1652. at Easby Church.

The effects of this fever remained by several distempers
successively. first after the Miscarriage. I fell into a most
terrible shaking Ague lasting one quarter of a year. by fits
each day twice in much violency, so that the sweats was great
with faintings. being thereby weakened till I could not stand or go.

After the Ague left me upon a medicine of London Treacle
I fell into the Jaundice,
[word] I.e., jaundice. which used me very hardly one full
quarter & a half more. I finding Dr witties judgment true that
it would prove a cronnicall distemper. but blessed be the
Lord upon great & many means used & all remedies. I
was at length cured of all distempers & weaknesses which
from its beginning had lasted 3 quarter of a year full out.

Thus I had a sad entertainment & beginning of my Change
of life the comforts thereof being turned into much dis-
comforts & weaknesses. but still I was upheld by an All-
mighty Power. therefore will I praise the Lord my God. Amen.

div.head:
A prayer & thanksgiving for my deliverance of my
first Child
August 6th 1652 August 26th 1652
; cast in this sickness. 17 hours.
div.p:
O Lord most Great, & yet our Gracious, & loving father
in our Saviour Jesus Christ thy dear son. Tender &
131
Dear as A loving Mother, who hadst a love to me in my
preservation from death, & destruction. in thy divine
wisdom hast thou ordered all things & passages in this
my great sickness, of my Life not laying more on me
then thou gavest me strength to undergo. O Lord this
dispensation of Afflictions & great sicknesses is the way
& means to bring me unto thee, & the fittest for me to in
joy. letting me see thereby thy mighty power to cast
down & raise me up again, even in my desperate cond
-ition when all men had given over to expect my Life

Then did the great Physician of Soul & body raise the one
& heal the other; raising me up again & giving me
strength & setting me on my feet after 6 months sickness
in my bed. I called upon my God, in mine anguish
of spirit, & heaviness, I did complain, & made my
supplications unto my God; the Lord of my Life & Joy.
for my desires was to cleave unto him, That I had offended
& made my supplications unto my Judge. O Lord I
have offended many ways, but thou art he that canst
wash & cleanse my defiled, polluted Soul for who is
there that liveth & sinnest not. As my desires was alone
to cleave on thee, so thou didst send this to me, this sick
nesse unto thy servant. And by degrees did remove the
same in thy due time. Thou heardest my prayers accep
ted my tears of repentance, my sorrows; when death
had compassed me about. Lord heal my soul for I
have sinned. And now o thou most holy one of Israel
blessed be thy glorious name, & magnified forever. that
thou hast put fresh opportunities of praising thee &
serving the Lord in the Land of the Living. Stir up my ???
& soul in true, & unfeigned thankfulness. to thy
divine majesty & never to be unthankful or ingrate
full. or unprofitable. in thy world:
132
or forgetful of these inexpressible mercies and
deliverances in my child birth, & all my other extreame
weaknesses which my soul had never seen before, till now.
Lord let me be kept by thy grace from any displeasing
thought of thee for thou art good & doest good all
-waies, & that this may doe me good Sanctify this thy
healing unto thy handmaid, let it encourage me to put
my whole trust & confidence, in thee alone, & that I may ac
-cept of the punishment of my iniquities, & learn by this
not to offend. & tho, thou O Lord art pleased to give me the
lesse comforts, here on Earth, I shall not much care. if that
I may enjoy the more of thy presence, here, & the full fruition
of thy self in heaven; & that thou wilt also make thy self known
to be a gracious God to me & to all such as rely upon thee
by faith. I know also that it is through thy dispen-
-sation that I am brought into the married Estate of Life, &
that thou in wisdom hast ordered each change and accident
about this my sickness, as to my danger & care. I beseech thee therefore
O Lord my God leave me not, for I am thine, & freely willing
to be at thy disposition, desiring thee to give me suitable
gifts & graces to serve thee in this calling. which by thy provid-
-ence I am entered into. And as I did not foolishly or lightly
put my self upon it, (with out begging thy direction) in which
my desires was unfeignedly to serve thee & trusting & relying
upon thee my guide. So dear lord leave me not, but let me
still find thy goodness & clemency, in comforting me in all
crosses, afflictions, sicknesses, & calamities, in soul & body
giving me faith, patience; humility; chastity; charity;
hope, & fortitude. with fixed resolutions to love, serve &
follow thee, to my lives end. that so I may receive the end of my
my hope in the salvation of my poor Soul. Lord As thou has un-
-ited our hearts in a holy union in marriage. so continue me
faithful, loyal; & obedient to my dear husband living
133
According to Christs institution. loving him with that
conjugal love thou requirest. bless him with a wise &
an understanding heart, & loving Affections to me his
Wife. that we living together in thy love & fear as
thou hast appointed may receive a happy crown of--
glory hereafter, I beseech thee also support me in all my
sadness & sorrows, & sicknesses. receive my hum-
-ble & hearty thanks & praise for my deliverances &
preservation. Make this fire of affliction instrumen
-tall to purge the dross of all my sins, of Negligencys
ignorances. & wilful transgressions. that I may come
out like gold out of the furnish. Then shall I praise
the Lord most high for all his benefits showered down
upon my soul. give us grace also to lead the rest of
our days in thy service, not swerving from thy Laws
or ways. but love thee & delight in thee. & sanctify
us with thy free spirit, that we may make good use of
all those opportunity thou puttest into my hand to
serve thee uprightly even all our Life long, that we may
give up our accounts with Joy & not with grief. All
which humble requests & petitions I crave with pardon
for our neglect in duties, & this mean performances that
I present, craving all things thou in wisdom seest
fit for me or my husband in soul & body I most
heartily beg in the name, & for the sake of Jesus that
thy Son, to whom with the holy Spirit. one God in
Trinity be all glory, Power, thanksgiving and domi
nion now & for ever more Amen. calling upon thee in our
Lord & saviours Prayer that he taught us saying: Our father

div.head:
Upon the Birth of my Second child, & Daughter
Alice Thornton, borne at Hipswell on the
Third 3d
of January, in the year. 1654.
div.p:
It pleased my most gracious God to have compassion
on me & to give me strength to conceive again
about a quarter of a year after my recovery of that
most desperate & dangerous Sickness, wherein I was
brought so weak that my speech was taken from me, not
being able to call for any help, but even as though
I were expiring for many hours together. & affterwa-
-rds, not able for many weeks to turn my weary
bones in bed nor help my self in the least. but lo be-
hold the goodness of God pleased to raise me up, giving
me a new life, & new conception, hopes of renewing
comfort, for that sweet infant he took from me before.

And albeit I bred my child in much illness, & sickness
appropriate to persons in such cases. yet the hopes we had
of comfort in this Infant by its life did much incou-
rage Mr Thornton & my Self to trust in the Lord, who
had brought me out of all my former extremities &
afflictions, to hope in him, in whom all things are Possi-
-ble for strength also to bear this Child.

Being about a 11 or 12 weeks gone. I perceived the child
to be quick, rejoicing in the Lords mercy to me. my child
was very lively about 3 weeks. & about that time I found
my self very feverish & hot, causing much sickness
at which time there was no motion in it, which made us fear
some further evil befall it or my self. Upon advice
Mr Mahum let me blood about 4 or 5 ounces.

When lo immediately thereupon. I found so great a
refreshment & cooling, that the child sprang in my womb
and from thence forward I had much health & strength
all the time of my being with child till with in a month of my
delivery. when growing big I was in a wearyish condi
ttion, till my travail came on me about the 1st of January
135
At night I was in much pain wakening so out
of my first sleep so, & continued very ill in
strong labour till Tuesday the 3d of January between
the hours of 5 and 6 a clock in the after noon.

At which time, I was with great & excessive torment &
Peril of my Life delivered through the infinite &
boundless mercy & goodness of god to me.
who gave me a sweet & beautiful, comely daughter
which was well nigh choked with Phlegm & the
navel string which was twice about her neck, & Arms
so that when she was borne she was with out any breat
-hing or appearance of life with the sore labour I had
she staying one full hour in birth at neck & should
-ers. O blessed be the ever living Lord God of mercy
forever more Amen.

Alice Thornton my second child was borne at
Hipswell near Richmond in yorkshire the 3d day
of Jan. 1654 Baptised the 5th of the same. witnesses
my Mother the Lady wandesforde. my uncle Mr Major
Norton
, & my cosen Yorke his daughter. at Hipswell
by Mr Michell Siddall minister then of Caterick.

div.head:
A prayer & thanksgiving for my deliverance
of my Second daughter Jan. 3d 1654.
div.p:
O: Most great & dreadful Lord God. And yet a
Tender & loving Father of Mercies in Christ Jesus
thy son. how hast thou appeared glorious in
thy mercy, fearful in thy praises doing wonders
how hast thou bin pleased to have compassion up
-pon me a poor weak woman labouring in hazard
of my life in great peril of death. thou hast given
me strength to conceive, after my great sickness
& then in mercy preserved that conception in my womb
136
with my self. Also from all violencys, hurts. falls &
all other dangers causing me to come to my full time
notwithstanding that ill fit I had at the first quarter

And now most graciously hast strengthened miraculous
ly thy servant to bring forth this sweet babe. though
with much hazard to her self & me, yet o Lord thine
Almighty power did alone work this great Miracles &
wonders in me & my Infant. O Lord to the hon.or of thy
Name be all glory ascribed that hast vouchsafed to
hear the desires of my soul, & bitterness of my dollers &
anguish, when I lifted up my cryings with my voice
uttered in sad distresses.

There is none able to doe as thou dost; who hast made
heaven & Earth & all things therein, on thee dependest
all things, & with thy outstretched Arm thou upholdest
all things that are. Holy is the Lord most high which has had
regard to his weak handmaid. O Lord my mouth is
filled with thy praise. Let me be ever in thy sight a than-
kfull grateful creature, And that thou maist receive
glory of men & Angels for this mercy to me.

I most humbly beseech thee, o merciful father, since
there is none besides thee who killest & makest alive let
let our lives be given to me & this infant for a prey. to be
a blessing to our generations. Sanctify & bless her from
the womb & she shall be blessed. Lord let her be a vessel
of glory to thy name & much comfort to her parents.

make her to be filled with wisdom, Chastity. holiness
& Piety to the Lord all her days, who hast had compassion
on her in this her tender Age & birth sparing her life
And Lord let me never be unthankful for these thy
infinite compassions & mercies with all thy former favours
at all times in all dangers & distresses.

But O Lord deliver me in the day of trouble, at
the day of death, & judgement for my Saviours his
sake cover me all my life long with thy shield of
defence. And as thou hast given me a new Life
I doe again acknowledge that I have received
it of thy own free grace & bountiful mercy prai
eng that these our lives may be spared in love & favour
to us & not as the beginning of further miseries.

O Lord strengthen my faith. hope charity with all
other christian graces, & give me a thankful ???
all my days. Receive my child into the number
of thy Saints, as thou hast given her the opportunity
of holy Baptism. Make her thine in Life and death
from her cradle to her grave that thou mayest re-
ceave the glory of thy name by Me for so great a
mercy afforded, in giving me a child borne a live
to our comforts. let us be replenished with wisdom
to educate her in thy true faith & fear, & provide
for her all things necessary for her soul & body.

And all these things I humbly crave with whatsoever
else thou knowest fit for me & mine I humbly crave
in the name & for the sake of our Lord & Saviour Jesus
Christ. Amen. Saying as he hath bid me. Our Father

div.head:
Meditations upon the birth of my 3d Child Eliz.
Thornton borne the 14th of February. 16554.
div.p:
I recovered not very well, of the extreme weakness
that followed for a quarter of a year after my child, in so
much that my milk was taken from me & so I was hin-
-dred from doing the natural duty incumbent upon us
mothers which troubled me much; but I must be willing
to submit to all Gods pleasure in every thing.

At some time my strength returned again And through
138
Mercy I conceived of another child having somewhat
a better time in breeding it and did fully intend by Gods
blessing to nurse it my self if I had strength;

About a week before my full time I continued in much
pain through the heaviness of my Child; having the mid-
-wife in constant expectation each hour. at which time
my dear mother laid sick in the house of a sad cough. &
young Mr Troutbeck came to give her directions through
some friends advice. & by the blessing of God she was recov
-ered though not to be with me in my travail. all tuesday
& that night with the morning on wednesday I was in great ex-
-treamity till I was delivered. which came to pass on wednesday
the 14th of february. half hour after 11 a clock in the forenoon
of a very sweet goodly daughter, & a delicate child, for
which most gracious mercy in my deliverance with my infants
I render most faithful & infinite thanks to the great & mighty
God of heaven & earth which had compassion on me in my extrea
-mity.

After I was delivered & in bed at 9 a clock at night.
it fell out that my little daughter naly, then newly weaned
& being asleep in the cradle fell into a desperate fit of
the convulsions, as it was supposed to be, her breath stopping
& grew blackish in her face. which did sore affright her maid
Jane Flouer, who immediately took her up & with Jane
Rimer the midwife made help to recover her life. but all
that night she was so exceeding weak that my Aunt Norton
sat with her & many others expecting when she would have
died.

During this poor childes illness, I was almost at deaths
door my self. by a great Illness coming after I was in bed
so that my Aunt & friends did imagine I could not live
nor durst they tell me how weak my sweete Naly was at
that time least grief should have dispatched me hence.
but they removed her in the cradle into the Parlour.

This ill fit hindered my milk much. but yet affter
-wards I recruited fast. & within a fortnight had gotten
the milk again into my breasts & my deare babe Betty
did suck every day of me & I was over joyed in that
great blessing. But it is usually so with me that I have
my comforts mixed with sadness. & many times my in
-joyments are woven with crosses. & sorrows.

For at the fortnights end. I was sitting in a chair & giving
my child suck, when immediately one of the maids
cried out of the nursery that My childe Naly was either
dead or dieing, which so affrighted me being but weak
that an Illness cam in force on me as I sat. & there was much
to doe to get me safe in to my bed, & there kept, betwixt
hopes & fears for my self & child 2 days. or more.
but at the length. through exceeding much mercy &
love of my God he brought us both from those weakness
& I recovered strength in time. and Naly had an
eye Tooth which broke flesh that had bin the cause of all that
danger to her. and often afterwards when her teeth
was cutting the gums she was ill again till she had
got them all.

But this second weakness of my own did so dis-
-courage my dear mother, that she would not let me
give suck, although I extremely desired it, & at
the months end I was forced to dry my breasts which grew
full & had endangered to bring me ill again.

And Dafeny Lightfoote gave my betty suck. till she
proved with child: which afterwards was the cause I put her
to another at about 3 quarter of a year old; but she did not deal
well with my child which was a most stately lovely girl
when she took her to nurse. nor was I able to go so
often then to see her because it was a mile off Hipswell
& I was then with child, so that I durst not adventure a
great walk or to ride when I grew so big.

Elizabeth Thornton my third Child was borne at Hipsw
the 14th of february. 1655 being on wednesday half hour
after 11 a clock in the forenoon; she was Baptised the 16th
of February by Mr Anthony. witnesses, my mother, my
Aunt Norton, and my brother Christopher Wandesforde
Mrs Blackburne stood for my mother being sick then.

div.head: A thanksgiving after the birth of my 3d childe Betty
div.p:
Oh, what shall I render unto the Lord most high for his
goodness, & loving, kindness, & benefits, showed unto me
or how shall I set forth all his praise, which am not able to
reckon up the least of all his noble acts, nor can I count them for
the number far exceeding the stars for multitude, that he
hath showed to me his weak handmaid. having added
many years to my days, & many new lives to my years
in his late manifold deliverances. I am not able to yield
his majesty sufficient thanks for his former mercies. yet
now has he heaped up a multitude of fresh deliverances
& preservation to my self & children, whom the Lord has
given me. I will sing of the loving kindness, of the Lord; &
with his corrections he will mix his mercy, & sweet smiles
of his countenance upon me. Therefore thou O Lord
most high art to be praised, & in thy Temple shall every
one speak of thy praise. Admirable in wisdom fearful
in praises & doing wonders. O Lord, our God whose mercy
reacheth to the Heavens, as great & many as the moments
of Eternity, yet hast thou humbled thy self to behold the
wretched children of men, & amongst the rest, on me the vilest
person by reason of my Sins. And hast opened thy hand
wide to fill me with blessings from above & the daily sweet
effects of thy loving kindness. Thou O Lord hast heard
thy handmade in all the distresses of my soul & anguish of
141
of Spirit Adding a new blessing to thy servant causi-
-ng me to bring forth my 3d child. of a comely body
& straight limbs & proportion. when my soul was
even at deaths door; thy mercy said reture.
[word] I.e., returne. & gavest
me a new life blessed be thy holy name & merciful gooness
[word] I.e., goodness.

Oh Lord most glorious Trinity, how can I set forth
thy praise, thy glory who hast bin to me & mine pitti
-full as a father. tender as a mother. careful as a
guardian. & exceeding merciful to all those that call
upon thee & fear thy great name as they ought.
hast thou only cast me & my child down & not
raised us up, no, for thou upheld me by thy love &
restored us again many times by thy providence
& more particularly in these late extremities when
could remove the same but thou alone.

I pray thee O my God to fill my soul with great app-
-rehensions & impresses of thy unspeakable goodness
long suffering, full of compassion & mercies that will not
always be chiding for ever, nor dealt with us after our
sins; nor rewardeth me according to my wickedness
Lord
has delivered me in my distress. Lord grant that
my gratitude may be as great as my needs of mercy
are. letting thy merciful loving kindness endure for
ever upon all thy servants & me thy handmaid &
on my two young children whom thou hast preserved
from death giving my little Infant life, health, & the
happy opportunity of holy Baptism. I pray thee
dear Lord make it be consigned by grace to thy
service and a member of thy mystical body. that she may
be preserved for ever. Dear Lord keep no anger
in store for my husband. self & children, neither chide
us not in thy heavy displeasure for then we perish for
ever.

But pardon our Sins heal our infirmities, cleanse our Polutions
& make us fit temples for thy spirit to dwell in. satisfi-
eing our mouths & ???s with good things. removing all our sins
with the guilt & punishment due unto us for the same as far
as the East is from the west. heal our infirmities & save our
souls from destruction. And give me I beseech thee a
thankful ???. a right understanding in thy Laws & precepts
wisdom, & discretion to govern my ways aright. with A health
-full frame of body that both soul & body may be serviceable
to thee. for these are mercies thou art pleased in.

And because I cannot praise thee according to thy excelent
-cy take my soul in thy due time into the Land of Everlasting
Praises. that I may spend a whole Eternity in singing Halelui
has to thy thy name to whom is due all hon.or power. domi-
-nion & glory of men & Angels. for ever Grant this for
Jesus Christ his Sake our dear Lord & Saviour. Amen.
Amen

My mother Gates, who was my husbands mother; died
at Oswoldkirke of a flux of blood by siege. as it was
supposed to have a vein broken inwardly which by fits
troubled her many years, having broken it by a vomit
of Antimony to strong for her stomach. she departed the
10th of May 1655. & was buried at Stongrave in her
husbands Alley, my father Thornton, whom she had out
lived 17 years, having all so bin married to him 17 years
& was buried on the 11th of May. 1655.

My Husbands Father in Law Mr Geffery Gates died.
at Hull the 18th of May. 1655 &, was buried at Hull the
same next
day: May 19th 1655.

My brother Richeard Thornton died in Dublin. in Ireland
of the Flux the 3d of July 1656. & was buried in St Patricks
Church the 4th July. 1656. This gentleman being twin with
144
My dear husband was the likest to him in all respects
both to Person & conditions, a most sweet affable
courteous nature, always ready to serve his friend.
& very well disposed towards Religion.

div.head:
Meditation upon the birth of my 4th childe Katherin
Thornton June 12th 1656. borne at hipswell.
div.p:
After I was with quick child of my fourth child I
had pretty good health, considering my condition, till
I was with in a month of my time. & then I grew very
heavy, big, & weary. full of pain; & the labour each
day was on me. I found the child more weighty & not
so nimble as naly & betty. so that she caused me to endure
more in a long pain before then the rest & I was one whole
week in travail very strong insomuch that I endured more
in that time & in the extremity, then of my other, & my fears
was much greater then formerly & I had greater ex-
-pectancy of my dissolution. my dear mother also did
fear me very much & she was pleased to assist me in
pouring out our requests to God for which she did in this
Prayer following:

div.head:
A prayer before the delivery of my daughter
Alice Thornton June the 12th 1656. by Alice Wandesford
div.p:
O Lord most high, the holy one who inhabitest
Eternity, & yet in mercy art pleased to look down
upon the Children of men, ordering & disposing all things
according to thy good will & pleasure. Wee thy
humble servants are prostrate before thy Throne of
Grace upon the bended knees of our Souls & Bodies
to acknowledge our unworthiness to appear in thy
Presence, much less to offer any prayers or suppli-
cations unto thy Sacred Majesty, for, besides that
145
Original Sin wherein we were conceived & borne,
we have committed many Actual Transgressions against
All thy holy Laws & Commandments, so that if thou
shouldest enter into Judgement with us, we could expect
nothing but death & Damnation; But forever blessed
be thy Majesty who hath not left us in this wretched
condition, But hast in thy boundless mercy provided
a Gracious Remedy in sending thy blessed Son Christ
Jesus in to the world for the redemption of mankind, those
whom they callest to the knowledge & true faith in Jesus
Christ. O Lord in the name & Mediation of this our most
Merciful Redeemer, wee humbly beseech thee to blot
out our Transgressions. and be reconciled unto us, that
our sins may not hinder our Prayers from ascending up
to thy Throne of grace, or there to receive a happy
Answer, not only in our own behalf, but for & in the be-
halfe of this thy distressed handmaid in travail of Childe
-birth in which Estate, and punishment for sin she doth
freely freely & cheerfully Submit, to thy wise dispensations
humbly beseeching thee to possess her soul with Christian
Patience in her greatest Extremity. Strengthen her
faith against the assaults of Satan. cherish her hope
in the second Adam Christ Jesus that according to thy
gracious promise he will break his head, by subduing
his power to tempt her to despair of thy mercies for her
deliverances. lay to her heart, dear Lord, those promises
thou hast declared in holy Scriptures to penitent sin-
-ners in their afflictions, And the gracious Performance
thou hast vouchsafed to thy poor handmade in sundry
such Necessities in the birth of her children. Oh wee be-
seech thee proportion her (patience) & pains, according
to that measure of strength it shall please thee to endue her
with, Oh Lord lay no more upon her then thou wilt enable
her to bear. with fortitude & patience.
146
Suitable to her sufferings: Send to thy poor Afflicted
Servant a safe deliverance, of a comely fruit of her
womb, of what Sex seemeth best to thy devine-
wisdome, Only we beseech thee grant that it may be an
Elect Vessel to Salvation that may live to be received in
to thy Church Militant by holy Baptism. And so
long after as thou hast appointed for the praise of
thy great name & a comfort of its Parents, further
wee are humble suitors to thy Majesty, to direct and
assist thy servant the midwife, that she may faithfully
discharge her office to the mother and the child, with
prudent wisdom and tenderness. bless her with
health & strength to finish this great work as thou
hast don heretofore, for many more, for which great
mercy both she, & wee here present doe praise thy
holy name, & doe likewise pray unto thee O Lord, to
bless our labours in the behalf of this our sick Sister,
by directing us all to those actions as may be most
proper for her assistance. But O Lord wee confess our
selves to be very great sinners in thought, word &
deed, we doe unfeignedly bewail our Iniquities the
rememembrances of them is grievous, the burden
of them is intolerable O Lamb of God have Mercy up
-pon us, & wash them away with thy most precious
blood; here & accept these our penitent prayers for
our Souls, & this thy Languishing Servant in peril of death
in Childbirth, Oh most Merciful God; Lay not her Sins
to her charge, but according to the multitude of thy tender
mercies doe away her offences, and accept her tears of
repentance & cries in Agony of Spirit for a safe &
speedy deliverance. And Lastly O Lord most gracious
I humbly submit my self to thy most blessed will
& pleasure, either for Life or death as it most Propor-
tionable to thy glory & Eternal good for soul &
147
Body; humbly begging. & beseech thy majesty that
if my dissolution be at hand; thou wouldest be fully
Reconciled unto me in Christ Jesus my Redeemer &
receive my Soul into thine Everlasting Kingdom
there to praise thee to All Eternity. All which we hum
bly crave of thee the blessed Trinity, Father Son and
Spirit, three Persons and one true and ever Living God
To whom be all praise. Honour, and Glory ascribed in
that most Sacred prayer. Christ himself hath taught
us Saying. Our Father which art in Heaven.
Amen.

After which humble petitions it Pleased our gracious Father
to grant our requests in a great measure for my pains of
travail increased, and although I endured hard Labour
I was delivered the next day.

Katherine Thornton my fourth child was borne at Hips--well
near Richmond in Yorkeshire: the 12th of June, 1656. being
on thursday, about half an hour after 4 a clock in the
afternoon, and was baptised the 14th of June. by Mr Siddall
witnesses, my mother, my neece Katherine Danby & Mr
Thornton.

div.head:
A Thanksgiving after the delivery of my,
Daughter Alice Thornton
of her being my
fourth child.
June 12th 1656. Baptised the 14th
div.p:
O most holy, Just and Merciful Lord God, who hast
Created all things in Heaven and earth for thy Glory,
Preserved them by thy Power, and hast appointed man
kind to increase and multiply for the Propagation of thy
Church Militant and increase of thy Church Triumphant;

Wee thy poor sinful Creatures, Dust and Ashes doe reno
-wnce all worthiness in ourselves to approach before thy
infinite Majesty, & therefore doe most humbly present our
prayers, praises, and thanksgivings unto thee in the name
mediation & Intercession of thy dearly
148
Beloved Son Christ Jesus, in whom thou hast decla
red thy self to be well pleased, and to accept the
Cordial devotions of thy faithful servants; In his
blessed name we we return to render unto thy Sacred
Majesty our bounden duty of praise and Thanksgiving
for thy wonderful, powerful, and merciful preservati
-on & deliverance of thy distressed handmaid & servant
from the pains & Perils of childbirth, And hath vou-
-chsafed to give her a comely child perfectly formed.
safe from harm; wee humbly beseeching thee, O Lord to
continue thy love and favour to this thy weak servant
in restoring her to her former health and strength if it
be thy blessed will that she may live to praise and
glorify thy great name, for this and the like preservati
on of her, To bring up this infant and the rest of her Children
in the true faith & fear of God, That her womb may be
a Nursery for thy Kingdom, strengthen her faith in
this weakness, that the Devil may not have power to tempt
her beyond her strength derived from thee, neither her
own frailties prevail in any ensuing distempers, sub-
ject to those in her condition, but in mercy dispose her
to quiet rest, and give a blessing in the moderate use of
thy good creatures for her food & Refreshment, with
an unfeigned thankful heart for all thy mercies, a
contented mind with thy most wise dispensations,
however it shall please thee to dispose of her self, her
Infant, or any other pledges of thy love, further wee
continue our prayers for this infant, that as thou O
Lord hast brought it by thy power, and in mercy forth
of the mothers womb to behold the light of this world,
So we beseech thee to give it thy seal in holy Baptism
Sacrament of Baptism, Thy holy spirits Illumination
to sanctify that Laver for its Regeneration, from Original
sin to actual Righteousness, as it shall live to years
of capacity.

Bless it with Good means for it's food, growth and
attendance & health. That it may escape the dangers of
negligence and other accidents incident to Infancy.
Lastly O Lord we praise & glorify thy holy Name that
thou hast blessed the Labours of thy servant the midwife
& the assistance of the rest here present. that it pleased
thy gracious goodness to afford thy handmaid convenient
help, strength, comfort of friends neighbours & other refres
hments to revive her fainting spirits. And now O Lord
that we have poured out our souls before thy majesty
wee had need to crave pardon, for our imperfect prayers,
& praises That it would please thee to forgive our sins
committed through weakness and Ignorance; And that
it would please thy gracious goodness to hear, receive,
and accept whatsoever we have faithfully & humbly asked
for thy weak Servant her infant, and our selves in the
all sufficient mediation of our most Merciful Redeemer
Christ Jesus the Son of thy love, concluding these our
imperfect prayers in that most sacred prayer which Christ
hath taught us to present unto thee to thy Glory, &
for our comfort. Saying. Our: Father &

div.head: Elizabeth Thorntons death; the 5th of September 1656.
div.p:
It pleased God to take from me, my deare childe betty
which had bin long in the rickets & consumption gotten at
first by an Ague & much gone in the Rickets which I concsed
was caused by ill milk at 2 nurses, And did notwithstand-
-ing all the means I used & had her with Naly at St Mun
gnos well. for it she grew weaker & at the last in a most
desperate Cough that destroyed her lunges, she died.
Elisabeth Thornton, my 3d Child died the 5th of september
1656. betwixt the hours of 5. & 6. in the morning. her Age was
one year 6. months & 21 days. was buried the same day at
Catterick by Mr Siddall.

div.head: A Prayer After the death of my 3d child Betty. Thornton
div.p:
O Lord most high, whose is the right of Creation &
Governor of all the Earth. I beseech thy gracious Maj
estie to pardon our great & crying sins, who hath
Provoked thee to deprive us of this sweet Child thy
Blessing to us. let thy favour over look our offences
& pardon wherein we have don amiss in all accidents
& occurrences of our lives, before, & since we knew each
other, forgive my impatience, or murmuring at thy
heavy hand. who yet in Judgement hast remembered
mercy & hast not pressed us to destruction. Lord look
not upon us as in our selves for then no living can stand
in thy presence. but appear polluted, defiled, & by
depraved nature Abominable in thy sight. but look
on us in thy dear Son Jesus Christ, our redeemer. and
pardon all our sinful compliances towards each other
since our married Estate if there have bin any such as
has displeased thee O Lord, for thou art a God of purity
& holiness, therefore cleanse all our hearts, & sanctify this sad
cross for our good & thy glory. to which I humbly submit
& freely, seeing thy goodness in delivering this my sweet
child from all its Miseries in this world. of Infancy
Childhood, & folly. And bless thy divine Majesty
who hast taken her a way, before her soul was polluted
with actual sins. hoping in my dear Saviour who recea
-ved, such when they brought them unto him on Earth
, that her Soul is acceptable in thy sight, whom thou hast
taken so early into thy Kingdom. O Lord give us grace
to live the remaining part of our lives in all holiness before
thee, & be willing to resign our Souls as this little child,
into thy merciful hands. be pleased to bless my other
151
Two Children with thy graces & favours, long life & health
with all opportunities to doe thee service, here being freed
from the bondage of sin, by thy sufferings. having grace
in their hearts. Bless also thy servant my husband
& my self with all mercies, graces, spiritual, & temporal,
fit us by thy Rod & support us by thy staff for thy heavenly
Kingdom, that we may in the mean time, possesses our vessels
in holiness; & Righteousness all the days of our lives, and
All for Jesus Christ our Lord his Sake. Amen.

div.head:
Upon my great fall I had, being with child of my 5th
September 14th 1657 at Hipswell.
div.p:
I fell with child after my deare bettys death, having
my health very well, after quick child & so continued
till I got a great fall over the threshold in the hall, at Hips-
well, being then great with child of my fifth, wanting but
Ten weeks before my time. on the 14th of september 1657
which fall cast me into an ill fit of a fever, and the Jaundice
followed, & a bout 3 weeks was very weak, & in great
danger of death, & miscarriage. with the continual pains
& excessive motions of the child in me, which was turned wrong
in my womb, by the fall, & might easily be discerned, nor
could it be able to turn the head aright, all though it kept
continual bending its back & body for it. so that Dr. witty
was sent for, & used all his skill in my preservation; and by
the blessing of God upon the means. I was delivered from
Death, and marvellously restored to strength at 6 weeks
end; I was let blood by the Dr with other remedies which made
me go to my full time. O what shall I render to the Lord
most high which had compassion on his weak handmaid.
Lord I am not worthy to live much less to receive all these
miraculous mercies from thy goodness for which I adore thy name
for ever Amen.

div.head:
Meditations on the deliverance, of my first Son
and fifth Child. At Hipswell the 10th of December
1657.
div.p:
It pleased God in much mercy, to restore me to strength
to go to my full time, my Labour beginning 3 days.
but upon the Wednesday the ninth of December I fell into
exceeding sharpe travail in great extremity so that the
midwife did believe I should be delivered soon.
but lo it fell out contrary. for the child stayed in the
birth & came cross with his feet first. & in this conditi
-on continued till thursday morning between 2 & 3
a clock, at which time I was upon the Rack, in bearing my
child with such exquisite torment as if each lime were
divided from other, for the space of two hours. when at
length being speechless, & breathless. I was by the infinite
providence of God in great mercy delivered. but I having
had such sore travail in danger of my life so long and the
child coming into the world with his feet first, caused the
child to be almost strangled in the birth only living about
half an hour so died. before we could get a minister to
baptise him although he was sent for.

I was delivered of my first son & fifth child on the 10th
of December 1657 he was buried in Catericke Church the
same day by Mr Siddall. this sweet, goodly son was turned
wrong by the fall I got in Sept before, nor had the midwife
skill to turn him right, which was the cause of the loss of his Life
And the hazard of my own.

The weakness of my body was exceeding great of long
continuance that it put me into the beginning of a consum-
ption, non expecting for many days together that I should
recover, and when I did recruit a little then a new trouble
seized on me by the loss of blood, in the bleeding of the Hemerobs
[word] I.e., haemerroids?
every day for half a year together.

Nor did I recover the Lameness of my left knee. for one whole
quarter of a year in which I could not touch the ground with it
this I got in my labour, for want of that knee to be assisted.
But, Alas all these miseries was nothing, to what I have
deserved from the Just hand. of God. considering the great
failings of my duties is required both as to God & man,

And though I am not given over to any sinful inormus
[word] I.e., enormous.
crimes which 1000ds are subject, to yet am I not pure in the sight
of God. for there is no man that liveth & sinneth not. what
cause therefore have I to cry out. Oh the height, the depth, the
breadth, the length, of the Love of God which had great compassion
upon the weak handmaid of the Lord which was destinated to
destruction, and did show me mercy in the Land of the Living
The Lord most high make me truly remember his goodness
& that I may never forget this above all his mighty & stretched
out hand of deliverances to me his vile creature. That I
may extol & praise the Lord with all my soul, & never let go
my hope from the God of my Salvation. but live the remainder
of my life he gives me to his hon.or & Glory and that at
the last I may praise him Eternally in the heavens. Bless
the Lord O my soul & forget not all his benefits.

div.head:
A prayer upon my preservation after the birth
of my first son. & his death.
div.p:
O Eternal God, who endurest for ever, and thy remem-
-brance throughout all generations, have pity upon me
according to the infinite treasures of thy loving kindness
hear the voice of our groaning, for thy indignation and thy
wrath lieth hard upon me. & my sins have put an edge upon
thy sword, and a thorne into my wounded consciences. O Lord
I acknowledge thy justice in the afflictions which thou hast sent
in my torments & the death of my infant. & thou mightest have
spared its life & taken mine. but thou in punishment remembered
mercy letting me still live to tell of thy
154
Inexpressible goodness & mercy to a poor destitute wretch
whom thou hast made of nothing to show the miraculous power
of thy Majesty & clemency. Lord God of heaven let not
all thy mercies be in vain but work that end for which they
are sent, for I am a weak worm & sinful dust and Ashes
not able to think a good thought, how can I pray unto
so great a God as I ought. O give I beseech thy servant
the spirit of prayers & supplication that I may pray a right
believe a right, & profit a right under all thy dispensations
& forgive thy handmaid if at any time I have too ear-
-nestly desired a son. & make me now to rejoice of thy
salvation, that thou o Lord hast saved my own life, give
ing hopes of a longer continuance to work out my sal
vation with fear & trembling for thou are a great and
Terrible God who may stand before thee. O build up the
Ruins of my Soul, repair the breaches of my comforts with
my dear husband. and our hopes of salvation, and let
thy glories now appear, for that shines brightest in the
beams of thy mercy, and when thou turnest unto the
prayer of poor wretched destitutes, it becomes an eter
-nall monument & a record of thy hon.or, & all generations
which shall be borne shall be borne to shall praise thee.
Look down O Lord; from thy Sanctuary, hear the
mournings of us; send me health & Life so long as it
may be a blessing, & doe not shorten may
[word] SiC ??? i.e., my. days in wrath
, but give me grace so to spend all my time in the works
of repentance & holiness, that when my years fail &
change come, I may be translated to the new heavens
which shall never perish & wax old, there to continue
and stand fast in thy sight for ever. And further receive
my hearty & humble. thanks & adoration & praise
for my great deliverances from these dangers of many death
& praise the holy Trinity. through Jesus Christ our Lord Amen.
Amen.

div.head: My Cure of Bleeding at Scarbrough August. 1659.
div.p:
It was the good pleasure of God to continue me most
wonderfully, though in much weakness, after that excessive
loss of Blood & spirits, in Child bed, with the continuance
of lameness aboue 20 weeks after, and the loss of blood
& strength by the bleeding of the Hemorrhoids, which followed
every day by siege and was caused by my last travail
& torment in Childbirth. which brought me so low & weak
that I fainted almost every day upon such occasions.

And it was the opinion of Dr wittie that I was deeply gon in
a Consumption. and if that continued longer, I should be
barren. All which being considered by my dear husband
& mother. they were resolved from the Drs opinion that I
should go to Scarbrough spaw for the cure of the said
distemper, & accordingly, I went with Mr Thornton staying
about a month there, in which time I did by the blessing of
God recover my strength. after the stay of the former
infirmity, of bleeding it leaving me with in 2 days, totally
& was cleared from those faintings this carried along with it
returning to Oswoldkirdke by my Sister Denton homewards

After this great cure which the spa wrought on me, for which
I most humbly return my hearty & faithful acknowledg-ment
of his mercy, we returned home to Hipswell, where we found
my Dear Mother some what recovered of a very
deepe Ill
fit of the stone in which she had bin in great danger about
2 days before. and had sent for me home, her servant meeting
me at my sister Crathornes, in my way to Hipswell; I was very
Joyful to find her any thing recruited from her extremity
blessed be the Lord most high, which had compassion on my dear
Mother in raising her from death, & easing her from those
violent fits of pain & torment, giving her to me. & sparing
my life also from that languishing sickness caused by my Child
-birth, & might have caused my Death.

About this August after our return from Scarbrough
it pleased God to give me much strength & health,
so that I conceived with Child; which after Mr Thornton
perceived, he with my mother greatly rejoiced; hope-
-ing that I might at length be blessed with a son.
For 4 months together, I enjoyed a great deal of
comfort & health, being much stronger & lively
when I was with my Sons then Daughters, having
great cause to admire the goodness of God, which even
contrary unto hope caused me to recover of that Sad
distemper, wherewith I was afflicted, and giving
me hopes to bring forth a Son to be a Comfort to my
dear husband & us all.

div.head: A thanksgiving after affter my recovery.
div.p:
My song shall be always of the loving kindness of
the Lord: with my mouth will I ever be showing thy
truth from one generation to another, O Lord, the very
heavens shall praise thy wondrous works: & thy
truth in the congregation of the saints. And now thou
O Lord who dost wonders, casting me down in sickness
& weakness, & raising me up again in thy good time
thou hast thereby declared thy power to all People
Let the observation of thy abundant mercies, & loving
kindnesses lately showed to me both in my deliverance
from Death & weakness as also in my strength to con
-ceave, make very deep impression in my heart &
memories, that when I am in heaviness, I may remem
-ber the years of thy right hand, calling to mind thy
wonders of old thou hast don unto me, that all though
thou sometimes withdrawest the brightness of thy
countenance from me, and shuttest up thy loving
kindness in a short displeasure in some sickness or
157
Affliction: yet I may now with a thankful heart full of
ardent Zeal & Gratitude give thee thy hon.or due
unto thy Name in these excellent mercies walking
in thy commandments like thy redeemed ones to whom
is showed such wonders of thy power & mercies.

And that the experiences of these thy old mercies, which never
fails, may sustain my infirmities, & the expectation
of thy loving kindness, may cure all my impatience.
till in thy due time, the sense of thy favours may actually
relieve all our distresses, and thy right hand lead me
like a sheep into the folds of eternal rest and
security through Jesus Christ our Lord. Amen.

About this time wee were all in a great confusion in
this Kingdom, none knowing how the Government of this
Land would fall, Some desiring the continuance of Oliver
Cromwells race to stand, others desired the return of the
Long Parliaments Power which had Acted the death of the
Blessed King, & to Establish their Arbitrary power
again, others intended through the weakness of Richeard
Son to Oliver, & then Ruled as Protector, to advance
the interest of Lambert, in Public Authority; which was a
man highly for independence; & so would have utterly
Destroyed both Church; & State; in lopping of all who had
Affection, or Dependency on either, Rooting out the very
face of a Clergy man, or Gentleman. or the Civiller sort of
the Commonalty: In this distraction, each man looked
upon the other strangely, none knowing whom to trust
or how to be secured from the Rage, Rapine & destruction
from the Soldiery in whose sole Power was both the Civil
& Ecclesiastic sword; since the year 1648. And we had
all suffered so deeply under those oppressions, that even
the contrary party to the King did heartily wish an
alteration, from those pressures.

Insomuch that most Sober, wise People of this Nation
began to have a good opinion of the Ancient Govern-
ment of this Realm, under which they had lived so
many Peaceable years, when they had smarted for
their fickleness in changing it, made them Experien
ce which was the best, & most desirable, for it's happy pro-
-ductions, of Peace & truth.

Thus did it Please the divine. wisdom, so to order it
in great & miraculous mercy, that when we had felt the
Evils of our Sad divisions, & our growing higher tow
-ards utter destruction in their continuance in them
, he thereby taught the Nation wisdom, & did incline
their hearts to return to their old Station, under
the Notion of a free Parliament.

As all the world stood amazed at our unheard of follies
& confusions, when the best frame of Government was
Pulled down & destroyed, so was there great combi-
-nations against us of all sides by our Enemies
to have rooted out our name & Nation.

And this by all People of several Persuasions & Relig
ions, would have bin glad of so Rich a Prise.

But he who is the keeper of Israel. that neither Slumbers
nor sleepeth, watched over us for good, & was a Tower
of defence against all our secret & malicious Enim
ies, & out of our own miseries made a way for to
Escape, even when they little thought of such a thing
yet till that time was come, great & heavy was our fears
& burdens,
[word] SiC ??? i.e., burdens. groaning under that tyranny both Church
& state, having our dear Sovereign King Charles the
2d banished, & not enjoying those rights, nor indeed
any thing from his 3 Kingdoms. which was unjustly de-
tained by usurpation, which caused us daily to pour out our
159
complaints to God, with incessant cries & tears for his
Church & Anointed to be restored again, which might be
the means of Reestablishment of the Gospel of Peace amongst
us and the true Religion in these, once flourishing Kingdoms.

div.head:
A Prayer to God for the Church. & restoration of the King.
november 1659.
div.p:
O Lord our God, the great & mighty Jehova, which hath
thy eyes open, to see the oppression & hear the cries of all thy
servants in all the ends of the Earth. Let not I humbly be-
seech thy divine Majesty, our misery seem small unto
thee, which we suffer in this place & nations, by reason of our
Sins, which have bin so great & crying that they have tired out
thy long suffering & patience, & we are abominable in thy
holy sight, in whose presence the Angels cover their faces
And yet o Lord. whither should we vile creatures go to
be cleansed, or purged: but unto thee the fountain of an in-
exhaustable goodness & Purity. We have sinned & don
amiss, O Lord & what shall we say unto thee, oh thou
preserver of men; Oh take away our wickedness & thou
shalt find none; Lord thy mercies hast upheld us these
many years of calamities even beyond miraculous, there
fore let our supplications come before thee the Judge of all
And make not a full end of thy Church in this nations
whose miseries has bin too long by reason of our sins.
Butt let it appear that in judgement thou wilt remember
mercy & spare us from utter destruction from the hands
of thine & our bloody enemies. O deliver not the soul of
thy turtle dove unto the multitude of her Enemies: and
forget not the Congregation of the poor for ever, which hast
no dependency upon man, nor dust & Ashes, butt in thee
alone. the Great & terrible Lord God. King of heaven & Earth.

Arise O God, maintain thine own cause: remember
how the foolish man blaspheameth thee daily, forget not
the voice of thine Enemies; the presumption of them that hate
thee, increaseth ever more and more.

But thou O Lord, Blessed Jesus, who with thy Precious blood
hast purchased to thy self, and redeemed A.
160
Church, that it should be subject unto thy divine Laws
& precepts serving thee in holiness & righteousness,
being delivered from Sin & wickedness, & from the fears
of all their adversaries spiritual & temporal.

Forget not the congregation of thy poor faithful ones
in this Kingdom forever, which serves thee constantly as
they are able with there utmost capacity & sincerity.
maintain thine own cause, & deliver us from the Mul-
titude of her Enemies; Preserve; & restore with thy right
hand all thy servants thy ministers of this Church, which
may dispense thy holy word & Sacraments, & are now
in a manner quite abolished. Restore we beseech thee
our dread Sovereign, to his Kingdoms which thou hast given
him to succeed his holy father to doe thee service in
Church & State, ruling them prudently with all his Power
in truth & Peace. And let a Cherubim's flaming sword
as in Paradise stand sentinel; and keep from the-
invasions of sacrilegious persons and the pollutions of
all impure Church Robbers, all thy dwelling places;
that thou maiest for ever dwell amongst us, defend
ing the poor, bringing help to all thy People; and par-
-ticular blessings and assistances to the tribe of thine
own inheritance, which thou hast sanctified to thy
worship and service. through Jesus Christ our only Lord
& Saviour & redeemer. Amen.

div.head:
A Relation concerning my dear & hon.red
Mother the Lady Wandesforde & of her
Death December 10th 1659.
div.p:
My dear mother, was Sole daughter to Sir Hewet
Osborne, & Lady Joyce his wife, which Lady Joyce
was Eldest Daughter to Sir Miles Fleetewood of
London in the Reign of Queene Elizabeth. of happy Memorie
She was borne at Sir John Paytons house. Jan. 5 1592
at Islellome- in Cambridgeshire, My Grandfather
* 1591 T Comber Old Miles 1592 N. S.

And Grandmother living then at my Aunts house at
Islelome, being the Eldest Child of my Grandfathers. & in-
tended by him to have inherited his Estate; having so
Entailed it upon her at his first going beyond sea.
in Callis Voyage. After some years he returned into
England, And it pleased God to give them A gallant Son
& heir, which afterwards proved a most Excellent, wise &
Good man, Sir Edward Osborne of Keveton, Baronet.
A faithful prudent man, Zealous for God, the King & the
Church, of great abilities to serve his King & country
Being advanced to be Lord President of york, &
lived & died in much honour & fame.

To return to my mother, who was bred up in her youth
& infancy with much care & circumspection by the Eye of
my Grandmother, a discreet & wise woman. giving her
all the advantages of breeding & good education. that the
court, & those times could afford, which was indeed excellent
for gravity, modesty, & piety, & other suitable quali-
ties for her degree, As writing Singing, Dancing. Harpsicals, Lute
&. what was requisite to make her an accomplished Lady
As she did approve her self in all her time.

At the Age of 21 years, she was married by the consent
of her Mother, being then her self married to Sir
Petter Frechvile, having lived seven years a widow
since my Grandfathers death; The Portion which my Father
received was very fair in those days being two thou-
-sand Pounds paid the next day of their Marriage.
Nor was she awanting to made a fare greater improvement
of my Fathers Estate. through her wise & prudential
government of his Family, & by her care was a means
to give opportunity of increasing his Patrimony. as
my dear father is pleased to leave upon Record in his
own book for her Eternal hon.our
so that it might be
said of her, many Daughters have don well, but thou
exceedest them all.

It pleased God to Enrich my Father & mother with the
(Chief end, for which marriage was ordained) the blessing
of Children. My Mother bringing forth to him seven.
hopeful, enough to live, & to be comforts to their Pare
-nts; four Sons, & three daughters.

The Eldest being Katherine; the second Christopher
who died at 6 years old, was a wise & beautiful
child endowed with Piety & parts, whose loss was very
deeply resented by his Parents.

The Third, was George, whom I have had occasion
to mention in this book.

The fourth was Joyce, a sweet & comely Child died
about 4 years old.
The fifth my self. Alice Thornton.

The Sixth, my brother Christopher Wandesforde
now heir to My father after my Brother George his
death.

The seventh & Last child was John, borne at
London before she went for Ireland, A sweet beauti
full & pregnant child; & young man, an Excellent
scholar & of Piety & parts beyond his years.

My Father being called over into Ireland to serve
the King in the Roles office in that Kingdom, by reason of
my mothers late weakness after her delivery of
my brother John went into Ireland, one year before
my mother & her Family.

After which she had a safe passage thither, living in
much comfort & happiness all my fathers life,
doing much good to all People, in each sphere
wherein she acted, laying out her self to the best
for her husband, whom she highly hon.red her Child
friends. & servants found there, as in England, a
perpetual effluence of all graces & virtues flowing
from so full a spring. which god had endowed her
163
Noble soul with all, lived in great peace, tranquillity, &
Charity, full of meekness, humility, Chastity, Modesty
sobriety & gravity; yea was she endowed with great wisdom
in the constant course of her life, of a sweet & pleasant com-
-posure of spirit, not sullenly sad; nor vainly light
