but of an Excellent Temper in soul & Body, neither of
them wanting those due ornaments, which might make
her lovely in the Eyes of God & man, And indeed Exact
-ly studious to advance the interest of her duties, in Piety
& Religion, in her self and all her Children, whose care
was very sedulous for their souls' happiness, as well as
the embellishments of their Persons; desiring to yield her
accounts to God in Righteousness & truth. according to the
sincerity of her soul in his service.

Thus were wee happy. & Blessed; that wee are Children
& offspring of such a holy & sanctified a Couple; whom
God Almighty had filled with such a measure of his Spirit
making them great ornaments of Religion.

After my dear fathers decease she lived his Widow
till her death; which was the space of 19 years & 7 days;
dieing in that same month of December & in old Age.
But she was not one of those that lived in pleasure, or
spent her days in vanity ; for what time could be spair
red from works of necessity, & duty, to her Children, &
family, All the rest was given to the service of her God,
either as works of Piety. & devotion; in private & Public
or Charity towards her brethren, whom she saw did stand
in need, & necessity. Especially having a due regard, &
compassion upon those Clergy, which through the Rigour
of those times of oppression, were banished from their own
homes; wanting all manner of relief, with their families
very often, & frequently found the bowels of a good sam-
-aritaine in hers; she opening her Arms, to receive Christ
in his poor members, Accounting it a great happiness
164
That he vouchsafed her the hon.r to be instrumental
for the Relief & support of such as were Precious in
his sight.

I have formerly made a discourse of her travels &
several accidents that befell her Person & Family after
my fathers death; till she came to live at her Jointure
at Hipswell; & also what troubles & trials, losses,
& crosses; she underwent almost all the time she lived
there, As well as from the unnatural actions, & unkinde
-nesse of friends, which had repining thoughts that she should
enjoy her Jointure. as from the Public Enemies &
disturbances from the Public Calamities of Church
& State.

All which she endured with a noble; & invincible spirit
being fortified by her Religion, & the testimony of
a good conscience, That she Laid out her self for
Gods service & Glory; & the good of my Fathers whole
Family, & the general benefit of Christians among
st whom she lived; yea even in those sad times of
losing all, many 100ds were Relieved, & supplied at
her door.

For her exceeding kindnesses don, for the help of the Heir
younger, Children, & debtors of my Fathers. let her
own narration, delivered from her in writing before
witnesses declare. what, & how she expended upon
that account; she being in a manner compelled to
leave such a testimony from some unworthy Prejudice
which said she did not much from her Estate for them

But it was requisite; for such an act of kindness
which she did, spending all she received, upon us that it should
not be forgotten. by that family. who received so grand
a blessing in her life & preservation, with out the which it is too
probable, that we might have bin made merchandise off.

Should I forget her unparalleled, wisdom, goodness,
tenderness, love, & Parental affection, by which she govere-
-ned all her gracious actions towards us, in our mainte-
-nance, & Education. I should be worse then an Infidel,
who had forsaken the faith & bin ungrateful to that God which
made them, & the very Ox & Ass which knows his owners
Crib, would rise up in judgement against me.

Therefore doe I desire in point of gratitude to God my
Father, & that gracious mother whom he gave me; to men
-tion those great mercies we received from her in general
And in particular for those exceeding goodness & favours
where in she extended her bounty towards me.

Who was pleased to provide an habitation for me after
her decease, & disposed me in marriage. After which I with
my husband & Children, did live with her 8 years after
my marriage, bringing forth 4 of my Children in her house
And had all manner of Charges, expenses, & household
affairs, in sicknesses, births, Christenings, & burials, of
& concerning, our selves & Children; with the diet &c. of
nurses, men servants &, maids & our friends entertain
-ments, all things don of her own cost & charges all her
days while she lived. which could not be of less value to
us dearly
[word] Jo ??? yearley? Anselement has 'cleerely'. See comparator below (n107). It is not 'yearley', it is cl- or d-. Which of the two, though... then 1600l

And no small addition of help to my husbands Estate
was her disposal of her Real Estate in Land, which she
had Purchased for 550l settling it upon my self, & my
Children.

Also her exceeding affection extended it self in her
settling all her Personal Estate by Deeds of gift, & her
last will & Testament, saving her Debts, & Legacies, &
funerals in feoffees in trust, for the use of my self,
H. & Children. All which I confess far exceeding my
merit, but not her entire affection, for my constant
being with her in her sorrows & solitudes.

And albeit she had in our minorities disbursed upon us
out of her own Jointure; which should have bin don out of
Kirklington the some of 2000l.

The some of 2000l besides, above 500l to my brother
George the Heir, with the payment of 300l Debt of that Estate
and the loss of all my fathers Personal Estate given her
by will as also; her loss of her Annuity of 300l per Annum
out of Ireland to the value due unto her at her death
19
years A
widow
the sum of 300 per Annum-which never received any part
thereof. yet notwithstanding all the aforesaid goodness
of hers to that Estate; there wanted not some who putt
hard thoughts into the Heir's mind, that she dealt hard
by because she did not give all her widow's Patrimony
to him, when as all her former helps did redound
to his benefit, & with all they knew our Estate was more
burdened at that time; which might require such
helps from her, because we were contented for the
Ease of Kirklington, to receive my Portion from thence
yearly & not in an Entire Sum;

Besides this she fitted my youngest Brother John W.
with the opportunity of good Schools, as Beedall. Chester,
Richmond, with all other provisions, of maintenance &
Books & all necessaries; for Cambridge, leaving him
under the Tuition of Dr widdrington in Christs Colledge
maintaining him there all the time, which by reason of
a sore fever that seized on him there, he cost her after
the Rate of above 100l per Annum.

All which time his Annuity Lay dormant in the Estate of my
father, which I suppose was some advantage to the Heir.
In fine, great & many were the good & Charitable Acts
this most dear & Excellent mother of ours did to us
all: she so wisely & justly disposing her Estate
Amongst us: that none had the least cause to complain
But bless God for her wise dispensation.

Being truly thankful for the safe protection care &
preservation we enjoyed under her wing.

In all our Sad times of calamity which our Eyes beheld
She restraining & moderating her own expenses, most
frugally; & good housewifery, that she neither lived in a penu
-rious, but a noble handsome, manner; to whom both our
Friends & her own was freely entertained, & welcomed
Her Poor Tenants was more happy in her, then many
of her bordering neighbours, who although exceeding
poor at her first coming; yet by Gods Blessing upon
her discreet ordering her affairs in her Estate that the
Tenants grew Rich after little time in those distracti-ons
And since have infinitely bewailed her loss whose person
Living they had so great an hon.or for.

It was very observable, that she out lived those sad
troubles upon the Kingdom in part though not till the
restoration of our happy King Charles the 2d whose come
ing was daily prayed for & heartily wished. And
the last Soldiers which quartered at Hipswell, Proved
to be such as turned to Generall Monke, from Lambert
& with in a short time the mighty Power & providence of
God, turned the minds & hearts of the People as a mighty
River towards it's own Channel. After her disease, which
she had put up so many Prayers to God for And would have
bin a Joyful day for her to have lived to seen.

But I hope God had prepared a great reward in Heaven
for her for all her Toil & Sorrows she endured in this
Bochim & vale of tears, & after 3 weeks sickness, gave
her the full fruition of her long desired happiness.

div.head: The relation of her sickness here follows.
div.p:
It pleased God to visit my Dear & hon.red mother
The Lady Wandesford, with her last Sickness. upon
friday the 17th of november 1659 beginning then with an
exceeding great Cough; which tormented her Body with
stitches, in her breast, & troubled her with short.
168
breathing; These stitches continued about 14.
days together hindering her from almost any sleep
or rest, in so much that it was wonderful how she
could subsist. But upon the use of bags with
fried oats, butter & chamomile chopped laid to her
sides, the stitches removed, & the cough abated, as to
the extremity thereof.

But then she was seized with a more dangerous Suim-
-ttome of a hard lump contracted in her stomach
that laid on her heart; with great pain, & rising up
to her throat. almost stopping her breath, when she
either swallowed any thing or laid to sleep.
Which lump was conceived to be contracted
of wind & phlegm in the stomach for lack of
voydance.

She had also an Exceeding sore throat &
Mouth, so that she was deprived of the benefit of eate-
-ing or swallowing, almost any kind of food save
a little drop of beer, being the most she took inw-
-ardly for 4 or 5 days, & that but with a searing.
her Tongue & mouth, at first was black. then it
turned white, so that with the pains my dear mother
took in washing & cleansing the skin came of
& was red till the blood came, this continuing, till
in the end her mouth grew white all over.

In this most sad condition of weakness was
my dear mother, almost quite with out food, Rest
ease, or sleep for about a week. In which time, as
also in all the rest of her sickness, she expressed
extraordinary patience. still saying, it was the
Lord that sent it to her, & none else could take it from
her, & if he pleased to see it fit, he could ease her
or give her patience to endure his hand.

Often would she say; that the way to Heaven was by the
gates of hell, And that the Lion of the Tribe of Judah would
deliver her. likewise would she frequently break
out & say with the sweet Psalmist of Israel, in the mid-
st of her inexpressible pains & torments. Why art
thou so full of heaviness, oh my Soul, & why art
thou so disquietted within me: I will still hope in
my God, & putt my trust in the God of my salvation
who is the help of my countenance and my God,

She frequently repeated the 71 Psalm, which she said
was penned for old age. Surely she was a great exam-
-ple & pattern of Piety, faith, patience, of fortitude
& Resolution to with stand all the fiery darts of Satan
which he in her weakness cast to affright, & hinder
her Journey to Heaven. but he in whom she putt her
whole confidence. & served from her youth up. did
not now leave her in extremity, but so assisted her
in soul & spirit that it was. an heavenly sight to the
beholders even to her last Period, & not withstanding
all her torments, still she put forth her self for the
Glory of God, & the good of her family & beholders
In good instructions, severe reproofs for all sins in
general with a continual praying to god & praising
him in Psalms suitable for her condition, speaking
to God in his own phraise & word, saeing that we could
not speak to him from our selves, in such an accapt-
-able a manner as by that which was dictated by his own
most holy Spirit. She often desired her friends to
pray with her, & for her, & told them that she desired that
they would not pray for her continuance in this life
for she was weary of it & desired to obtain a better
& to be fitted for it; And that these should be the heads
on which they should Petition God for her Videlz.

That the Lord would be pleased to grant her true
170
And unfeigned repentance for her Sins, which he had
mercifully pleased to begin in her already, & to per-
-fect the same.

To give her pardon, remission; & forgiveness for
them, through Jesus Christ her Dear Saviour.
To grant her, true faith in him to believe all his
Promises in the Gospel. & laying hold on him for
salvation, with the sanctification of his holy Spirit
And at last, to Glorify her in heaven in his good
time. which petitions said she, whosoever shall make
for me; the Lord hear and grant the same.

This sweet Saint of God, had always a great and
unfeigned love for all Gods faithful Ministers and
often desired their prayers, giving great attention
to them; having much comfort in her Soul after that
ordinance. Her desires was earnest to receive
the holy Sacrament, which she did with great comfort
on Thursday was sevenight before her departure.
from Mr Petter Samewaies. although it was with
great difficulty of swallowing; she never tasting
dry bread after, for that excessive weakness.

Her desire was to Mr Kirton, he would preach her
funeral sermon, The text to be out of the 14th of the
Revelations: verse the 13th Blessed are the Dead that die
in the Lord: for they rest from there labours &c.

This blessed Soul had the gift from her God to
continue till her last breath, her perfect memo-
-ry, understanding. & great wisdom & Piety, ever
preparing her soul for God & recommending her self
in devout ejaculations, crying out with St Paul.
I desire to be dissolved & to be with Christ; And all that
friday night before she departed having this sweet
saying in her mouth Come Lord Jesus, come quickly.
she making Dafeny to pray with her, that prayer of Dr
171
Smith made in his Book for a Person at the point to die
& took great notice of each Petition praying with
Zeal & ardency.

It was very observable in all her sickness, as in-
deed she was not wanting of her gratitude to God
for his exceeding testimonies of his love & mercy
to her in all her preservation. & deliverances of
her & her Children, which she very often repeated
severally enumerated in her best health, So was
it now in her grand weakness & torment, even till
her death. still the subject of her discourse, calling
to mind the wonderful & infinite goodness of God to
her even from her childhood, setting forth his
favours to her Soul: & spiritual mercies innumer-
-able which she particularly mentioned; And then
she mentioned all her manifold preservation, &
deliverances of her person from death, & destruction,
making such an excellent catalogue of all; that it was
a great consolation to the hearers, & proved by these
things, as a great argument of the support of her droo-
-ping spirits now at the hour of death; being a strong
bar of defence against her spiritual adversaries

That God had appeared Gloriously for her that was his
servant, who had delivered her from time to time
when ever she called on him: her Lord never forsaking
her; but brought her to the gates of death in a happy old
Age & to the sight of heaven; where she fain would be
And in him she alone trusted through the merits of Christ
he would still deliver her from hell, & Sin, & Satan, &
Preserve her to his Kingome, there to Live with him for
ever, where she might spend the whole Eternity of Praise
& thanks giving & Hallelujahs of glory to the Blessed Trinity
Till which time she was thirsting, & longing, & desirous to be
dissolved & to be with Christ Jesus her Redeemer.

For nothing of this world, nor in it could hinder
her fixedness for Heaven, nor indeed, did the concer
-ness of this Life come into her thoughts, saving to Leave
her Pious & Christian, instructions, & holy adminitio
-ns amongst us her Children & Servants, & to learn
by her how to live well & die happily, Joyfully, & comfort
ably embracing &, often calling for death; to let her
in to the enjoyment of her Lord.

She had made several times in her sickness upon occa
-sion of ministers visiting her: many very excellent
confessions of her faith, & profession of those Christian
foundations upon which our faith was built, & of her
true Zeal to the service of God in his wholy ordinances
of our most Pious & Christian Church of England
wishing us, & charging, as we would Escape the danger
of Damnation. not to dishonour that great God whom we
served by reouncincing that faith & Profession which
was taught us by the holy Clergy & Bishops of
England. never to listen to the insinuations of any
factious new doctrines what ever. but serve God
truly and sincerely therein. & he would accept of our
Souls, & we should be happy; if not in this world; yet
hoped in a better: And that she did believe, that if we
humbled our selves for the abominable sins of this nation
& pray to god faithfully, & serve him sincerely in ???
God would return in mercy. & restore his decayed
Church in England; & his servants son Blessed King
Charles the first Posterity to Rule in this Nation,

Praying heartily we might be delivered from Popery
which these divisions & schisms might tend to. if not
prevented by the all wise providence of Almighty God
As to her own particular: she blessed God for making
known to her the truth & preserving her therein. declaring
that she made it her constant endeavour to walk there in
all her days, having her direction & guidance from God.

And now she found the comfort of his service & the hopes of
the rewards of his grace which he gave her through out the course
of her Life, & felt the sweetness of influences upon her
Soul for which she most humbly rendered all the Powers &
faculties of her heart. in thanks & praise to his name &
Mercy for ever.

She Poured out her fervent admirable Prayers to her God,
for all her Children & relations, begging for each perti-
-culer Child those graces. & gifts they wanted; And for-
givenesse to all who had any way, wronged; or injured
her in all her life naming some, who had more nearly, &
highly wronged & grieved her, with the bowels of compassion
for the good of their souls. that they may repent & be forgiven
& received to mercy in his Kingdom where all ???s are
united in the holy band of Charity.

As to my own Private concerns, she Petitioned God that
I might Might find comfort in my husbands Family,
& be rewarded with the same blessing that God had bin graciously
pleased to give me, in my Children, (as she was pleased to say
I had bin to her); And that I might be strengthened by his
grace to endure those afflictions with patience, which I must
find in this world after her death. & that I might have hope
in Gods mercies, that he would lay no more on me then he would
enable me to undergo, & that they were signs of his love to me
& that I must not grieve too much for her Loss, since the Lord had
continued her so long to me. for he could make up her loss
in a greater comfort by giving me a Son which I wanted; &
that I was then with Child of one; wished me continue as I
had begun; & then we should receive each other with Joy in
Heaven; which she was confident of through the merits of Jesus Christ
according to his speech to St John. Be thou faithful & I will
give thee a crown of Life. with abundance of other heavenly
Rich expressions, that I am not able to write down.

She told me she had fully finished her will & settled her
Estate according as she,
174
Desired; & she hoped with a good Conscience settling all
she had in such a manner as would breed no trouble. &
that she hoped her son Christopher would be satisfied
with it because she had not bin a wanting in the discharge
of a good Conscience towards him ever since he was borne
by taking pains with him, & care of him in his Minority
and disbursing the greater part of her widow's Estate
upon him, or for his brother John, or the other Part of
Kirklington, whereby he had the benefit of her maintain
ing the Children. And that now he would let me enjoy with
my husband & Children what she had don for us.
considering my husbands Estate needed it, & he was
heir of a great Large Estate of his Fathers & by her
Death that Jointure came in clear to him. All which Estate
would amount to yearly to him in England & Ireland
three thousand Pounds. which she prayed God to bless to
him & his Posterity. that they might enjoy it in righteousness
so long as the moon & sun indureth.

And now she said I have don my work & finished my
course, which the Lord had given me to doe, hence forth
I hope is laid up for me a Crown of Glory, which the Lord
shall give me. & not only to me but for all those that love
the Lord Jesus. & his appearing.

About thursday night she sent for her Children to
take her last farewell in this life, when Mr Thornton
& my self came, with our 2 Children Alice & Kattherine
she desiring my husband to pray with & for her, as he had
don several times, in which she was much pleased & sattisfi
-ed, ever Joining most devoutly reverently, praying with
her heart & soul in each petition, finding great Joy
& refreshment upon such occasions.

After which prayer she embraced us all severally in her
Arms & kissed us; pouring out many prayers. & blessings
for us all. like good old Jacob, when he gave his last
175
Blessing to his Children, she begged of God Almighty
for us all; After which I took the saddest last leave of my
Dear & hon.red mother, as ever child did; to part with
so great & Excellent a Parent & infinite Comfort.

And yet the great grief I had was increased by
Reason of her exceeding Torment which she endured; which
made me more willingly submit to part with her, who
I saw endured much pains & extremity, not desi-
-ring she should long endure that which it was the pleasure of
God for the Exercise of her Patience to lay on her.
Also, when she see me weep much, for this affliction of
hers, did indeed concern me nearly.

She Said, dear Child; why will you not be willing
to part with me to God; has he not lent me, to be a comfort
to you long enough; O part with me freely, as I desire to
enjoy my Saviour, in heaven; doe not be unwilling that
I should be delivered from this miserable world, give
me willing, & freely to him that lent me thus long, & be
contented in every thing. You never have bin disobe
-dient to me in all your Life. I pray thee obey me in
this that you submit cheerfully to the wise & good determin-
ation of our good God. And fill your heart with spiritual
comfort instead of this in me he takes to himself. And
so the blessing of God Almighty be upon the head of you &
yours for Ever Amen.

Certainly the words of a dieing friend prevails much.
& I doe believe the Lord had put words of persuasion in to
her mouth which prevailed more then all the world with me to
moderate my excessive sorrow; & build me up in hopes; as
she said of our meeting again. never to part; which so
happened, for I was after this even desirous that if it were
the determinate pleasure of God to take her from my head
that I might patiently submit, when he should free that sweet
Soul from all those burdens of pressures & extremities

It pleased God she continued till Saturday; About
noon she spoke to my uncle Norton, & recommending
My self & all her Children to his care with much
good prayers for him & his she then took her leave
of him. About 4 a clock my Aunt Norton came to
see her, when she saluted her gladly, biding her well
-come dear Sister, what comfort is it to me to see my
dear & hon.red husbands Sister with her at that time
there ever having bin a strict league of affection &
friendship betwixt them, she was then come to see her make
her last end; & Scene of her life whom she had known
near 40 years. & so took her solemn farewell. of her
I forgot to declare that about wednesday before. she called
for her Last will. it being made a year before that And
made it be read all over before her; confirming, and
Ratifying the same, & publicly declared the same to be
her last will & Testament before my husband & my
self & Many other witnesses, making the same to be
endorsed on the back of her Will &c.

To return to her last actions in this Life, About
6 a clock at night this sweet Saint of God began
to be speechless; having still all that time employed that
Tongue in nothing but prayers, Praises & Petitions to
God. with most heavenly Spiritual & pathaticall
recommendations of her self to the Lord ever saying
Come Lord Jesus make haste & receive my Soul
& at the last immediately before her speech failed
Lord Jesus into thy hands I commend my Spirit.

And when it failed still lifting up to heaven her
Eyes & hands to God. And Dafeny perceived she
drew her breath short & going to depart prayed her
That She would give them that was with her a some
signs that she found the comfort of Gods Spirit in her
Soul; with a taste of the Joys of Heaven;
177
Which she immediately did to all their great Comforts
for she lifted up both her Eyes & hands steadfastly
to heaven three times, distinctly one after another.
And closing her Eyes her self, then laid down her
head & her Eyes:
this holy saint, & Matrone of true
Piety sweetly fell a sleep in the Lord. between the hours
of 8 & 9. a clock at night upon Saturday the 10th of
December: 1659 being the day of her Coronation I
hope in heaven, with her Father, Receiving that welcome of
Come the blessed of my Father, receive the Kingdom he has
Prepared for you.

For I was an hungry & yea fed me, naked & yea clothed
me, Sick & imprisoned & yea ministered unto me.
In as much as yea did it unto these yea did it unto me
And I hope she is now Entered into the Joy of her Lord:

My Brother Christopher wandesforde was then at London
where he was writ to inform him, both of her Sickness
& death. Her funeral was solemnised with as much
handsomeness as those times would afford & considering
the condition wee were in the soldiers having bin quartered
amongst us. Though not according to her worth & quality.

She was interred upon Tuesday the 13th of December following
In the Chief Place in her own quire at Cattericke Church
She having Repaired the same all that summer at her
own Charges to the value of above twenty Pounds.

Her Corpse was carried out of her house by the Lord
D'arcy. his son Coll. D'arcy. Sir Christoph. Vivill Baronet.
& divers other Persons. & kindred of quality.

Then from Hipswell greene. her Tenants. took her; &
so carrying her to the Town of Catterick. where the ministers
who was appointed by her own nomination Carried
her into the Church; & after Sermon laid her in her Gave
[word] I.e., grave.

The ministers names were these. Mr Petter Sammois; Mr
Kirton, Mr Ferrers; Mr Edrington, Mr Bindows, Mr Robinson
Mr Smith, Mr Brockell. Mr Parke. Infinite numbers of
Poor were served by dole at the door above 1500 besides in the
Church of Cattericke.

This blessed mother of mine was thus gathered in
to her Grave; having lived many Peaceable years
together with my Father, brought him a competent
number of Children, being the support of his house and
Family, Preserving it & the branches under her care
& Prudence, living his Chaste wife; (& widow for
above 19 years.

her whole Age where in she lived, was Threescore
& seven years, and 11 months, & ode days
so that she died in a good old Age; full of good works
& virtue & hon.orour to all of her Family & Country
To the Lords most Infinite Majesty be all Glory
& praise for his great goodness & mercy extended
to me, & us all through this dear Parent of ours
He make us to possess those graces & virtues which he
Bestowed upon her; that we may be the better capable
to doe him true & faithful service to our lives End.
Amen.

div.head:
Several Prayers made by my Mother proper for the
time of the holy sacrament. as Ejaculations.
Before receiving of the bread.
div.p:
O most gracious God. which hath Sacrificed thine
only begotten son to appease thy just wrath for
my sins, & to ransom my Soul from hell; Seal
unto me by this blessed Sacrament, thy promise &
covenant made in Christ, that thou wilt receive
me, a penitent Sinner & true believer into thy Grace
& mercy, & that for the death & Passion of my
Dear Saviour; my Sins past, & present, may
be remitted & forgiven, as verily, as I shall now be
partaker of this blessed Sacrament. Amen.

div.head: Before Receiving of the wine. after consecration
div.p:
O Sweet Saviour from whom I have received the
Inestimable benefit of my Redemption, grant that
I may receive the Spiritual Graces Signified by
these outward Symbols and pledges of thy love.
And that as my body is fed and strengthened by
Corporal food; so my Soul may (from the hunger
-starving of sin), bee strengthened by thy blessed
body, & washed by thy precious blood from all her
sins. Amen.

div.head: After both bread & wine.
div.p:
Grant O, Merciful Redeemer as thou hast vouch-
-safed me to sit at thy Table, and be partaker of thy
Precious Body & Blood, so my sinful soul may be
washed from all her Sins in that blessed Lavacre,
and buried in thy grave never to rise up in Judgement
against me: Forgive O Lord the want of the
preparation of my heart to come to so heavenly a
Banquet, in which are all the treasures of mercy dis-
-played, accept the poor and true endeavours of my
heart to the reverent receiving of thy holy Communion
, and grant that being now made partaker thereof
it may be effectual to confirm faith, & renew all thy
heavenly Graces in me, with the assurance of my salvati
on, being guided and established by the sanctifica
-tion of thy holy Spirit to walk in newness of Life
by a holy, Pious, & charitable conversation before
thee all the days of my Life.
Amen. &. Amen.

div.head:
My delivery of my Son William, my 6th child; & of his
death. April the 17th 1660 at St Nickolas my Aunt
Nortons house. after dear mothers death.
he died
April 28 buried 1659 at Easby 29. near my Lady
Whartons grave at Easby.
div.p:
After my dear Mothers decease; I remained at
Hipswell, by reason of my weakness. & trouble
upon her death. having gotten a very dangerous
Cough with watching with my dear Mother, for whom
I could never enough show my infinite duty & affect
tion to such an Excellent Parent.

Also, it was in a great frost, so that I could not well
be removed with Safety of my life till the march following
At which time I was carried to St nickolas, there rem
-aining till I was delivered & well again.

And it was the good pleasure of God to continue
me in the Land of the Living. And to bring forth my
6th Child at St Nickolas.

I was delivered of a very goodly son, after hard
labour & hazardous; yet through great mercy I had
my Life spared & was blessed with a happy child
about 3 or 4 a clock in the morning upon Tuesday
the 17th of April. 1660 borne & baptised that day.

That day also was my Child baptised by Mr
Kirtton of Richmond called William after his father
his sureties were my Cosen John yorke: my Cosen
william Norton. and my Cozen James Darcy Lady
of Richmond (died April 28th 1660) buried 29 at

Thus was I blessed with the life & comfort of my dear
child's baptimse with its enjoyment of that holy seal of
Regeneration; & my pretty babe was in good health
sucking his poor mother to whom my good God had
had given the blessing of the breasts as well as the
womb of that child to whom it was no little Sattis
faction. while I enjoyed his Life (buried
[word] SiC ??? i.e., buried. at Easby.

But it so pleased God, to shorten this Joy. least
I should be too much transported, that I was visited
with another trial; for on the friday sennight after: he
began to be very Angry & forward.

After his dressing in the morning: so that I perceived him
not to be well; upon which I gave him Gascon's Powder
And having had 3 hours sleep his face when he a-
waked was full of Red round spots like the Small Pox
being of the compass of an halfpenny; & all wealed white
over. These continuing in his face till night.
but then, whether through cold upon his dressing
then, or what else was the cause; the Lord knoweth. the
spots struck in, and grew very sick all night. and
about 9 a clock on saturday morning. he sweetly
departed this life, to the great discomfort of his weak
Mother; whose only comfort, is that the Lord I hope has
Received him to that place of rest in Heaven, where little
Children, beholds the face of their heavenly Father,
to his God, & my God; whom I humbly crave to pardon
all things in me which he sees amiss, & cleanse away my
sins by the blood of my dearest Saviour. & Redeemer

And that my soul may be bettered; by all these chastise
-ments he pleaseth to lay upon me his vile worm. &
unprofitable servant under all his dispensations. That
hath laid heavy upon me for these many years, Where
by he has corrected me; but not given me over to death
& destruction. for which I humbly magnify his Glorious
Name for ever. And I most heartily beseech him to san-
-ctifie these fatherly rebukes, & make them profitable
to my poor Soul to bring me in the possession of Patience
nearer to him self by a strict communion to see him with
Joy above all this Earthy Comforts or enjoyments. That so
I may be better prepared for acting to his Glory here &
here after; Even for Christ Jesus his son's sake. Amen

My Son will.m Thornton was buried at Easby in the
Same grave with his Eldest Sister which died before baptism
by Mr Kirton. he being scarce fourteen days old.
his father being much troubled at his loss whom the Child
was Exceeding like in Person & also his Eldest Sister.

div.l: Tax not thy God, thy own defaults did urge.
This too fold punishment, the Mill the the Scourge
Thy Sins the author of thy self tormenting
Thou grindest for sinning, Scourged for not repenting
I doe not beg this Slender inch to while.
The time away, or falsely to beguile my self with Joys
Here's nothing worth a Smile.
What's Earth, or in it.
That longer then a minute.
can lend a free delight, that can endure.
Oh who would droyle, or delve in such a Soil.
Where gain's uncertain, & the pain is sure.

div.head:
A thanksgiving for the restoration of King Charles
the second. of his Coronation May. 29th 1660.
div.p:
After the Lord had taken my Child from me. I had
some weakness upon my body by reason of the return
of my Milk, but in much mercy I was restored to
a pretty degree of strength. & staying at St Nickolas
till I was perfectly recovered.

In this time we had that grand blessing to the whole
Nation given to us in the restoration of our Dread Sover
aine Lord King Charles. when we each moment feared
Ruin & destruction. being in that concern, so wisely
& prudently ordered through the Providence of God that
notwithstanding, the opposition of the Soldiery & other
great factions; yet was he brought in, to his own
Kingdom; City of London, & Parliament in great Peace
& exceeding much Joy from all parts of the Kingdom
without the power of one dog that durst open his mouth, or the
loss of one drop of blood shed in the whole Kingdom.
[word] SiC ??? i.e., kingdome.

A maine instrument of our deliverance, was Generall
Monke, whose faithful heart God stirred up to be instrumentall
for this blessed change, desiring to Join with the Consent of
the best in the Nation, who Petitioned him for a free Parliament
183
All the way as he came out of Scotland from following the
factious Army of Lambert through each County was he
Alarmed with there cries, & petitions; hoping there by that
this might be the best way to Establish Peace in Church &
State, & reestablish the King in his Throne in hon.or & Safety.

Thus by the infinite goodness of God, this was effected acc-
-ordingly, for immediately after That Parliament was
called & set; They voted with great alacrity, his majesties
return in hon.or & safety to his Kingdom, after 12 years
banishment or there about; And now the ???s & tongues of
all faithful Loyal People in these Kingdoms was even full
of Joy. & admiration: not knowing how to show forth there
exceeding content & satisfaction, with gratitude to the great
& Eternal God of Gods & King of Kings, who had delivered
our Souls, & Bodies from those thraldomes. Restoring his true
& faithful Doctrine; & his vicegerent upon Earth to us.
Which requires our utmost possibility of thanks. & praise to our
great Lord whom we serve. Oh that our hearts might never
forget what he hath don for us in restoring our King. our
Priests, our Prophets to this our Land of our nativity. but adore
the Glorious name of Jehova for ever Amen.

div.head:
A Prayer. & Thanksgiving for deliverance
from destruction of the Kingdom: 1660.
div.p:
O Eternal God; King of Kings, and Lord of Lords. thou
that hast bin pleased in the fathomless, depth & boundless
goodness of thy mercy to restore our gracious King &
lawful sovereign next unto thy majesty to rule over us
And hast thereby made a way for us to Escape our own
destruction, which our sins & crying enormities & bloodshed
committed here might justly pull upon us. even the innocent
that hast bin slain in our streets crying for vengeance upon
us miserable sinners; & the putting out the light of thy true
Gospel thy word & sacraments; doth fly to heaven for just
-ice against such sacrilegious wretches, what shall we say
or can we sufficiently lament these horrid actions. If thou
184
Lord shouldest have bin extreme, nay, if thou hads not
over looked these abominations. for thy holy Sons Sake.

We had bin endlessly miserable to all Eternity; & this which
Nation had bin an Accelldama, & spectable of thy Justice
to all the world. But as thy long suffering & patience hast
still pleased to be a God full of compassion & clemenency
[word] SiC ??? i.e., clemency.
in sparing this many years & restoring our Lord again
& thy Church: the way to our salvation, being made kno
-wne to us thereby. We most humbly, beg & beseech thy
gracious majesty, to let our petitions be acceptable in the son
of thy Love, which intercedes for thy repenting servants

That our sins & abominations; of what nature soever, may
be cleansed & washed away, never to offend thy pure
Eyes, & give us humble & repentant hearts & souls, for
what is yet in us amiss; that thou Lord may have the glory of our Conve
-rsion & deliverance, from sin & hell; & that we may be
truly, & unfeignedly thankful to thy Divine Goodness
goodnesse; For thy Miraculous Preservation, & delive-
rances of our Lord King Charles, from all his Malicious
Enemies & the Churches: with thy favour in giving him
his Fathers Kingdom: thus quietly & peaceably;
with out the shedding of any blood amongst. Lord God
most mighty let the wonders herein makes us amazed
at thy Power, thy mercy, thy glorious Attributes of favo
-ur, where with thou upholdest the Sons of men. who in the
midst of our sins, confusions, & blasphemies, thou brought
letest us out of that darkness; setting us again in thy light
of the Gospel & truth. Oh Lord. make us by these signal
Miracles of thy Love, & free grace, as also by thy corrections
to walk for the time to come; with holy & upright ???s accor-
ding to these infinite Treasures of thy Power & mercy. that
we may not be an ungrateful People: But that both King &
Priest, Prophet, & People may give thee thy due Praise
& Glory in our lives & Conversations, We beseech thee as thou
hast set a Crown of Gold upon thy servant the King his
head.

And given him Power & Command to Rule this thy People
with justice & Piety, so doe thou hear the requests of
his lips, grant him the desire of his heart. in thy true faith
& prevent both his desires & requests, with the blessings of thy
goodness: & grace: give him great hon.or & reverence in
the sight of his People, whom thou hast restored to each other

And of all the Nations round about: let all his Enemies feel
thine hand, & put them to flight that rise up against him or
thy Church; that when thou hast given him the blessings of
A long life & Prosperous Reign blessing him with gracious
Posterity to succeed him in this Throne & Rule for thee.
he may at the Last be crowned with Everlasting felicity, &
Reign with thee in thy Eternal Kingdom;

And that both we, & our King, may know thee the God of our Fa-
ther. serving thee with a perfect ???, & willing mind, who hast
saved us from destruction of all our Enemies at home & abroad
putting a hook in their nostrils. Even so oh Father, for so
it seemed good in thine Eyes deliver us still by thy Power
& watch over us by thy Providence to defend this Church
& State from sinning against thee, by Treasons, backsliding
& Rebellions. That we may live at unity & concord amongst
our selves having the Lord of Hosts for our Captain & defence
And fighting under his banner, may overcome all the Spirituall
wickedness in high Places and at Last overcoming in thy
strength. may be crowned with victory & Glory.

Therefore to thee, the Lord Most high doe I humbly prostrate
my soul, & body with its utmost capacities, & all my facul-
ties of mind & ??? for that thou hast vouchsafed me the
meanest, vilest creature, unworthy to live; yet hast
thou pleased to hear the petitions of my Soul, & hast aga
-ine Reestablished thy truth & holy word, & sacraments
freely for thy servants to enjoy thee therein. with Joy & delight
& hast restored thy servant our dear King to be a Patron
& defender of thy Church & its members, let us all be so also
of that mystical body of our Lord Christ. united in faith & love:

And hast given me that happiness which thou hast denied to 1000
186
In this Kingdom to Live to see these things come to pass
with my Eyes, which had gon through so many changes
& alteration. at last doe I behold that which is our Joy & comfort
& the answering graciously of all thy Churches distressed Prays
& tears. To the God of our Salvation doe I in particular
And in general with all this Church Militant Render &
ascribe: All Possible thanks, Glory, Adoration. Praise
Power & Dominion, both in heaven & Earth. of men, &
Angels, To the ever blessed Trinity. for these his infinite
& inexpressible mercy to me & this Kingdoms for ever
and for Ever. Amen. Amen. ??? ??? ??? ??? ??? ??? ???

div.head:
Upon my Husband, & Families Removal from St
Nickolas, to Oswold Church. neare Newton. June 10 1660.
div.p:
After my strength was again Recruited through Gods
mercy for travail; We removed: with my Husband & those
Children, the Lord had blessed me with Alice, my Second, &
then Eldest, & Katherine, my 4th Child; and came to Osw--
oldkirke living a fortnight at my Sister Dentons
house till our own in that Town was ready.

Then we got to it with all my Dear Mothers household
stuff which was brought thither, where we lived two years
After I had taken leave of my own country, & dear
friends & Relations; parting with them with a sad heart
Amongst whom I had lived many comfortable years.

But God was pleased to go a long with me in a strange Place
making me to find many sweet influences of his favour
both in sickness & in health, and giving me comfort of
my Husbands friends, instead of my own. & to find a
great deal of favour amongst strangers where I lived
so that in all Places, & at all times, & upon all occasions.
I have daily fresh cause, & occasions to admire the infinite
goodness of that God whom I serve, desiring to speak well of
his name, who has pity upon his weak servant.

Here I lived for 2 years till our own house at Easte-
Newton could be finished, which we had bin in building.
187
several years before my dear mothers death. which if we
could have finished, before, She would gladly have lived
with us here, but it was not begun time enough for that;

In this time while we were at Oswoldkirke. My brother
Denton Preached there. & did that with much gravity & Piety
being indeed a very excellent good. & wise man from whom all
our Family had received many assistances & helps from
by way of advice; & chiefly my Husband, who depended
much on his counsel after our coming thither.

But he having some scruples, did not conform to the now
Established Government of the Church; so that he did leave
that Church after a while. & retired to live with us at
Newton. I confess his nonconformity did much trouble me
& I endeavoured with my small mite to discourse that business
but I suppose he had bin otherwise ordained then Episcopal
so that it was fruitless to persuade,) otherwise, it might
have bin better for us all. though he was ever of a quiet &
peaceable temper; free from faction, or disturbances of the
state: And indeed I enjoyed much comfort in his ministry
And great Assistance, as toward the building of our house at
Newton;
Mr Thornton not giving himself to take pleasure
or trouble in any thing of that nature: being much addicted
to a Melancholic humour; which had seized on him by fits
for several years before he was 20 years old.

Nevertheless; after the use of great means. which God directed
Me in by Dr wittie &c. as Leaches & gentle course of Physic
Spring & fall as there was occasion. ever since we were
Married; those were much abated. & he oftener was in a
more cheerful frame of spirit then formerly. as both he
& his friends. has often times acknowledged. to my great
comfort: whose utmost endeavours. & care, was ever to
study his good & satisfaction. in whose life & welfare my
own did much subsist. yet after his house was don & we
in it he took much content in it. when he was well.

In this time while I lived there, about Shrove Sunday 61
I was in the Church when it was a frost & snow, sitting in the minis
Pews. I felt my self exceeding Cold. & by fits continued till the
tuesday following. very ill:

div.head: My great Sickness at oswoldkirke february 13th 1661
div.p:
I began a dangerous Sickness, which brought me very nigh
to Death; at oswoldkirke after my dear mothers death.
which was caused by that Cold I got. & Aguish Temper on the
Sunday in the Church; causing a very violent vomiting
coming greatly upon Shrove Tuesday. feb. 13 1661 being
that day my birth day.

And so continuing perpetually in pain & vomiting
till I was not able to receive any kind of Sustenance.
being then fallen into an Intermitting fever. So that at
5 days end, I was compelled to send for Dr wittie.

He saw cause to let me blood, giving me many Cordials
to strengthen the stomach; but nothing would stay with me.
Till I drank a draught of cold water, which more refreshed
my Thirsty Soul; then all what Art could give:

That night being the 17th of feb. I did verily believe, sho
should be my last in this Life; I being brought into an
Exceeding weakness & feebleness of Body & spirit.
But most of all into a seeming Spiritual desertion
from God: which was not to be long endured. with out sinking
under the Pressures of the divine displeasure. Which I apprehe-
-nded in this my weakness. my Eternal State to be in a
Lost condition, by reason of my Sins; And Satan's
Accusing me falsely from my sorrows, & temporal sufferings
Casting multitude of doubtings into my heart. As that
Surely I did not belong to God. And I was not his Servant
because he followed me with such crosses, Afflictions, sickness
& troubles in this world; which seemed to be Curses; rather then
such trials, as he used to lay upon those that were his Children.

And that I had neglected, al those offers, & tenders of mercy
in his word & Sacraments, which he from time to time, had given
me from my youth up. in the examples, instructions & admoniti
ons from my dear Parents, & from his, ministers; All his
great deliverances. & checks, & calls of his spirit. with his
spiritual & temporal preservation of me innumerable.
(yet said Satan) All these had not wrought a through conver
-sion, & change of heart in me. to walk according to the motions
of Gods spirit with that strictness I ought to have don. & that though
189
I had bin kept from the falling into any enormous sins,
yet for the least ommittion of duties; or small offences a-
gainst God or man Eternal damnation was due; And that
now it was too late to (repent) or hope, because I had neglec-
lected, or driven it so long that my Life was at an end.

For ought I know this was my last Summons. And that all
though God was able to have mercy upon me: yet I had
so often failed my promises, & fallen into sins & forgettf
-ulnesse of God; That he now would not have mercy on me
at the last hour; As satan would haue persuaded me.
These with many arguments against my poor Soul: did
the old Serpent seek to destroy my hopes of mercy. & my
own weakness & melancholy forming against my self
joining with Satan; in fears because of my unworthiness
or ingratitude;

Lo in this most sad & heavy condition was I in; not
having any soul living that I could open my griefs & thou-
-ghts to nor receive any comfort, for my dejected
heavy spirit; for that time Mr Thornton; was himself in a sad
condition, & very melancholy full of trouble of spirit, nor
would I acquaint him least I should be an aggravation of
his trouble. And Alas, what could I say in this exigent
When the God of Mercy: by his corrections severe, had
seemed to forsake me. & with draw his presence; The Devil
Accusing: as he is termed the accuser of the brethren, my
conscience could not excuse me from too many failings.

My sickness & weakness threatening my desolation each
Minute; and I had none to give me Spiritual comfort
And my Soul was sad even to the death; yet in this exigent
whither could I fly for relief; but to that Great God which made
heaven & Earth: I desired to cast my self solely at his
feet, of mercy; yea before the Throne of the most gracious God
in whom I live & move, & have my being, saying with Eat
Easter
if I perish, I perish. here I am, Lord though thou
shouldest kill me, yet will I trust in thee, for healing,
pardoning, strengthening grace & mercy. Immediately upon
these thoughts, It pleased him in a wondrous manner to be
-gin to give me some comfort from sinking in my hopes, & to
stay my self on him, when I was almost past hopes by reason
of my weakness. this I obtained out of that
190
Blessed Portion of Scripture. which our dear Saviour spake
in St Matt. the 11 chap. & 28, 29, 30 verses;
which like the
Lightning breaking in to a dark place; thus it pierced
into the secret darkness of my sorrowful heart & dejected
Soul; bringing refreshment & some hopes of relief & comfort
being increased in the consideration of those heavenly mercies
contained in that scripture. Looking upon this as his sweet
& effectual call to my soul, wherein he then bid me come
unto him, & alone seek of him that had strength, power, & mercy
to relieve all poor sinful dejected souls, which laboured &
were heavy Laden, with sins the saddest burden then to be borne
Come unto me all yea that labour, & are heavy Laden
and I will give you rest.

Behold the handmaid of the Lord: I laboured under, & was
heavy Laden with the burden of my sins. under the burden of
Satan's bondage; & slavery of fears. the one bringing me to
wards despair, the other of torment, persuading that time was
past for any help from God, that the Devil might wreak his ancient
malice against souls, on me, in my sickness & weakness
then, being the fittest opportunity to prevail: when he shakes
there faith: Butt Lo in this my distress; the Lion of the
Tribe of Judah put to flight for me, as he had don for him-
selfe, when he tempted him to question his sonship; The
Prince of darkness: with this word of his, Come unto me. show
ing thereby that he was a liar. & that it was not to late for me
to repent & believe; nor him to accept of my soul, & so
by this he vanquished his strongest stratagem by which he
surpriseth the poor doubting Christian when at the Lowest Ebb
this he trieth if by any means he can make him doubt or
question the rich goodness that is Eternally in God as his very
being, & so commit the great sin against his mercy, from
whence flows mans Salvation. & then he is lost forever.

But at this time, when I was weakest Christ Jesus the Righ
teous came into my heart with healing under his wings
making it appear that Satan was a liar, & that he never refuseth
any who come unto him; according to that place of: those that
come unto me I will in no wise cast of. He calls, he invites,
he persuades sinners to come unto him. he it was that give me
191
This word; & set it home by his Spirit; to stay my
drooping heart; even ready to faint & perish for want
of spiritual food. Behold I was weary with the burden of
Sin. & he Said come: I was faint. & heavy Laden, he
said come: Lord I come, but to whom must I come for relief
come unto me, all yea that are weary & heavy laden. & I
will give you Rest. O Lord if thou art pleased to call all
that labour, & are weary: with there sins; & temptations of
Satan. I see no reason why I should not come with my sad
nesse & burdens, for thou hast promised to give me rest.

Alas o Lord God, I need it & want it, I almost sink und
-er thy heavy hand of displeasure: I cry unto thee, out
of the whales belly of despair: if thou help not. O God
the father of heaven have mercy upon me; O Christ the
Redeemer of the world, have mercy upon me. O holy, blessed
& glorious Spirit have pity on me: O Most glorious Trinity
3 Persons & one God, help thy poor distressed weak hand
maid. Plunged in the depth of sin & misery. for the least with
out repentance, & thy mercy is in it's own nature damnable
And non but thy own Almighty power is able to help
deliver & save me from the Jaws of this Lion; who goes about
seeking to devour & make a prey of my soul. And as thy
wisdom & free grace o blessed Trinity. did set thy self on
work by & through mercy to the sons of men, & by All mighty
Power to find out a way for mans Redemption: and of thy
free grace thou o my dear Saviour suffered the wrath of thy
Father on the Cross to purchase our salvation. So now art thou
pleased to vanquish my grand Enemy by the power of thy
word to me. I believe, (Lord help my unbelief) that thou
art as merciful to me as others, & wilt not exclude me except
I exclude my self, & as thou hast pleased to give me plenty of
Calls & comforts, who in my sad hour was a God of compassion
so thou hast given me grace to come unto thee. I come O Lord to
thee & hang on thy mercy, with all the Powers & faculties of my
heart & soul; for the pardoning my sin & to strengthen my faith
Though weak in body. yet with an unfeigned hope of thy
goodness & sweetest Clemency. that it will not be in vain this
thy word came unto me, this is from thy goodness when I was
in sorrow, to let me see if the time was not past, when thou calls
to come unto thee.

Thou most sweetly like a loving father showing me the way to
life ever lasting at that present when in my heart was in doubting
then to call unto me thus; is a mercy transcending my capacity
& with all to tell me that whom thou lovest, those thou chasten
every son whom thou receavedst. & therefore I may not
question thy precious love though never so sadly afflicted
I come, o Lord my God: and willingly take up thy sweet
yoke & desire to follow thee, my light, my Path, my way
O learn me to be patient, meek, & lowly in heart, to submit
to thy dispensations: for thy burden is light. but my sins
are heavy: yea thy ways is wisdom & pleasantness in
perfect freedom. Let me, now thou hast set my feet at
liberty, make thee for ever my Pattern. my comfort my Joy
my life & direction, so shall I find rest to my soul.

Rest. O: how sweet is that word to my Languishing soul
O let me find rest from sinning from offending thee any more
It is too much that I have spent so many of my years in
doing so little for thee. Let me now work for thee while thou
hast putt an opportunity of life into my hand, love thee &
delight in thee. & fear nothing but thee; spending the re-
-mainder of my days to the Glory of thy name. Not sinning
by an unprofitable life. nor give Satan any advantage
to tempt my soul to despair: by remissness in duties and this I humbly beg
with the return of my health, & strength if thou seest it fit
for Jesus Christ his sake the great Shepherd & Bishop of my
Soul. in whose name I further say as he has taught me
Our father. Amen.

After this inestimable & wonderful mercy, in my grac--
--ious Gods giving me satisfaction in my doubts & in putt
ing to flight that old serpent the Devil, from doing more har
--me to my soul then scaring me into the firmer & deeper
rooted Assurance, that the God whom I feared, & served in what
measure I could, was of so infinite a goodness. I was bound
to believe his word: That at what time soever a sinner re-
penteth him of his sins from the bottom of his ??? he will
put away all his wickedness out of my remembrance saith
the Lord. & accept him to mercy.

Which I hope he at that time gave me a great experience of
And was pleased to suffer my soul to receive comfort &
lifted the light of his Countenance upon me: making me
to enjoy a great share of Peace of Conscience & Joy in his
salvation; with the refreshings of my spirit in the testimony
of his love: in so much that all fears of dieing were taken
away: & then I was more willing to depart when he called
then to live in this vale of sin, & misery, if the Lord should
see it fit.

But Lo I asked spiritual: & the Lord gave me great
addition of temporal mercies, filling my mouth & soul
with abundant gladness & praise, when I looked for nothing
but death & destruction. showing that the mercies of the Eternal
God are not to be measured by the weak apprehensions of men
but admired & adored, in all his wisdom, goodness & free
Grace to poor wanting mortals.

For he appointing, means blessed the same to me. so that by
degrees I was strengthened in body, & in a great part recov-
-ered health though not perfectly, for a quarter of a year being
brought so exceeding weak in my sickness.

But with in a quarter after: I found my self with quick Child
which was a miracle to know or believe. And a blessing beyond
hope or expectation. after so dangerous & desperate a
sickness. wherein the Dr wittie did believe, it was impossible
I should retain Conception; after those violencys & ex-
treamitys of vomiting &c. which loosened the womb extremely
but for ever blessed be the most high & Powerful, & gracious
goodness of our God: which rebuked the fever; giving means
to help the weakness of nature: & restoring strength
abundantly to a perfect recovery. The Lord enlarge my
heart in all gratitude & thankfulness to walk uprightly
before his Presence all my days Amen.

div.head:
Upon our coming to live at newton after the house was
built in the year 1662 June the 10th
div.p:
At the last, after 6 years work at the dwelling house of
Mr Thornton Easte newton. having built it from the
194
Ground: It pleased God to give us all leave, with our
family & two daughters to come to live at it being
so finished, as to dwell therein about the midst of June
1662 I being then great with Child walked from oswold
kirke with our company. having a great deal of strength
& health given to me from God. Blessed bee his holy name.
Also he gave us a comfortable settlement at our own house
which I got ready furnished with what my dear mother gave
me in 5 days time. And all the ground stocked with her Cattle.

After which, with in a little of our coming to house: Mr
Thornton was called to London by nettletons business
going purposely to prevent the breaking up an Excecu
-tion against him from that Nettleton against his Estate
for a debt of my fathers, which Mr Thornton had bin ad-
vised by some to secure out of his own Estate: & to in-
gage for it, so till he could receive the monies from
Ireland out of my Fathers Estate there, which was by his
Lease for 41 years appointed to pay all Debts Legacies
& Portions in feoffee in trusts hands, & he had bin advised
formerly to take upon him the management of it from
my Uncle Mr Norton by way of Assignment. & to pay
those things chargeable thereupon; but albeit there was
a good Estate, which was 1000l per Annum.
there from whence
these debts should arise; yet it was altogether against
my dear mothers, or my own judgement or advice that he
should take upon him so great a trouble as that must be
both in regard that neither his Purse nor person was suiting such
an enterprise. being in another nation so a hazard to
his Person; & likewise not suited in other respects to with
stand the disputes, which she foresee would arise from some
that were concerned for themselves. Nor was there the least
necessity for him to engage in it for gaining my 1000l there
by reason both that & all other rights & dues which could be
challenged by my mother & my self were sufficiently
secured to us by my dear fathers Last Will & Deeds. &
non could prejudice us therein. what ever sinister pre-
tensions were made by others whose advice he unhappily
195
followed: as it after wards appeared. And besides my
English Portion was sufficiently & undoubtedly safe & se
cured to him; of 1500l by the will & Lease from my uncle Will.
Wandesforde out of Kirklington. & by Articles 3 partite
before my marriage betwixt My uncle Wand. my Brother
Christopher & my self securing both the 1500l & the 1000l out
of Ireland in its due order to be paid.

But it so happened that he was advised with out our knowledge
or consent as aforesaid to engage to Nettleton, (as well as
to the business of the Assignment) for a Debt of 1000l Payable
out of his own Estate by statute. because nettleton would
not accept of security out of Ireland: nor stay till Mr Th.
received it thence; but he prosecuted Mr Th. with so much
violency & fierceness; that he compelled him to borrow monies
to satisfy his clamour: & he had paid him 900l &
above: nor would he be satisfied: because the bond was for a
1000l & not being taken in by Mr Th. he sued for the whole
& for charges.
And most unjustly & deceitfully, watch
an opportunity when Mr Thornton was at London to have
dispatched it. he got an Execution broke up: and by his
own man, with 4 other Bailiffs came early in a morning; to
Seize upon all our goods, monies, Plate & till he were all
Satisfied: at first very stiffly demanded 800l then to
be paid But at last by my Brother Dentons endeavours
he knowing the debt was paid prevailed to give them 200l
which they would have, or Plate & to that value.

This accident, was very afflicting to me, in regard that I hoped
Mr Thorntons being there would have prevented it; & being
big with Child, the grief I had with the fright & the Rudeness
of those men, had nigh gon to make me miscarry, what for
the injustice & unhandsomeness of that concern which came so sud-
-ainly on me in that business. yet the Providence of God had so
ordered, that there was 100l of Mr Thorntons newly the week be-
fore come in: and with 57l of my own, part of what my Mother
gave me: that satisfied them at present. or else it might
haue proved fare worse with me then; in that condition. which if
I had wanted peradventure they might have taken my
bed from under myself & Children, & those quick goods
my mother gave for our Relief.

I pray God forgive all those, by whose evil counsel
my dear husband was brought into those snares: when
he intended most good to all parties in the acceptance of
the Assignment; And the very Troubles, vexations & affli
-ctions it carried along in the whole course of Transactions
often times brought us into straits: & great danger of my
Life. proving one sad ingredient to my other sorrows:

And indeed; I did fear some hard measure; to fall
unawares to Mr Thornton. & partly told him my conject
ure. offering to pay Nettleton off with those monies my Mother gave
me before he went to London; but he good man did not believe
nor could imagine that he might find such treachery in
those Lawyers he employed.

yet did my suspicion prove a means in part to arm me with
patience to over come that trouble when it came. Thus have
I upon every occasion; & act of my Life fresh cause to
speak good of the Lord my god who though he pleaseth
to suffer me to have afflictions of several sorts; yet with
the affliction he maketh a way to escape, and does not
permit more to come on me. then he gives me strength &
assistance to go through.

Therefore will I give thanks unto his glorious Name &
speak of his praise, in the Land of the Living. who hath not
yet given me over to death & bonds And I beseech his
mercy: that for what ever trouble I endure here from men
through oppression, or injure; he will endow me with a
double Portion of his Grace; here to serve him with a free ???
& patient spirit: & giving a competency of these outward
enjoyments for our selves & children in this life; if it be
his pleasure not to be burdensome to others. And in the end
to be our Portion & our inheritance for Ever Amen.

div.head:
Of the grand mercy I had in the first Sacrament at Easte
Newton after we built the house August 1662.
div.p:
Since the sad & dismal times of distraction, in Church
& State. the People in most of the northern Counties was
much deprived of the benefit of those holy ordinances of the
197
Word & Sacraments: but especially of the Latter. which with
the use of our Lords Prayer: was wholly laid aside, as under the
notion of Relics of Idolatry & Popish superstition;
So that lest wee should offend God by serving him in his own
way & command; (superstitiously,) & pray to him in his
own words; there was found out an other manner of
worship; by presenting to his Majesty prayers contineu-
ally out of our own brain composed; & that with out Premedi
-tation too often; and the Lords Prayer was by too many
despised as dry & insipid; by others neglected out of a
compliance with the times: Also; the holy sacrament: which
was the Testimonial of the highest Act of our Saviours love to us
lost men; was had in contempt as useless to the Church of
Christ through some men's high flown purity & gifts:
imagining themselves above those ordinances. who was
comd already into the state of Perfection.

In what a condition then may it be thought the true Church of
God was here in in England, and the members thereof. when we
were cut of from the comfort: & Joy we received, in & by
the holy & reverent use of these transcendent ordinances.
given & appointed. as his last will & Testament; to us, & all
his who should
have be
partakers of the benefit of salvation
through his bloodshed: And the breach of his loving command
doe this in remembrance of me; when in & by the use thereof it
was
ye presence the comfort
, & confirmation, of all that holy martyrs, &
Saints of God which suffered persecution for the testimony of the
Gospel of Christ:

No wonder then if we were brought into such plagues &
confusion in this Land, whose Pride was so great; & devoti
-on so dead: but we, who thirsted after these waters of life
did still, all these times; after my dear mother came to Hips-
well, & well as at weschester enjoyed this blessing; through
the mercy of God: even all the time of my mothers life to my
exceeding great satisfaction & comfort; but after her death
& my coming from St Nickolas, into my own house at
Easte newton which was above two whole years; I had not
had any opportunity of receiving:

For there was not then any minister at Stongrave which
did administer the Sacrament: nor had don there for
many years: so that I was holy destitute of an opportunity
to perform that comfortable refreshing duty which my Soul
longed for: & grieved much for the want thereof: And with
all being in such a languishing condition as I formerly
mentioned: with out any spiritual help from men:

After which drawing near with in a month of my delivery
it behooved me to look with a more narrow search into my
Soul & examine how my thoughts & desires were inclined
to accept of death; whose time of life here: very probably
might be short. this was my 7th child which the Lord had given
me to conceive. I had more strong apprehensions of my
change, in regard it was both my husbands mothers num-
ber & my own; This did more lively persuade, that as de
-ath waited at all times: yet more reason for us to expect
It at these strange & miraculous times of Child bearing
especially, as they have bin to me more then many others
motives of examination of my Estate & condition spi-
-rituall, of the growth, or decay of Christian graces which God
had wrought in me; by reason of my several trials & sorr
owes came on me: in the whole course of my Life: & whether
I had returned due thanks to God for the same & removal
of his hand of afflictions in my deliverances.

Upon which I found that for the want of these holy ordinances
& that by sad experience. that these troubles of the world; had
had interrupted; or diverted my free communion & close
walking with God as he had required of us not to be taken
of from his service & precepts for any worldly enjoyment
whatever, nor crosses should be my hindrance: but alas
such was my weakness that I had broken those solemn vows
of Baptismal; & Sacramental too frequently: through
negligence: Ignorance, wilful sins & worldly imployments
so that I had impulses upon my heart. & great desires to re-
new this grand strengthening. & quickening, & confirming
ordinance of our dear saviour: desiring in all true & un
fained Repentance: faith, hope & Charity: to be made
199
A partaker: of this comforting & confirming; holy Sacrament
which our Lord Jesus Christ left us as his dearest pledge of his
love & free grace: who laid down his Life for sinners, (that
sinned not): who became poor; that we might be made Rich.
through his grace & righteousness. Making a new covenant
But I could not obtain this happiness in regard that the mini-
-sters had not given it on this side during the wars: nor was
it again established here since the coming in of the King;
neither indeed had wee any minister settled at Stongrave our
Parish Church which was a great grief to me that had never bin so
long deprived of all these Public ordinances; nor was I in
a condition to travel any whither: so that I called to mind
that good man Dr Samwaies; who had given the Sacrament last
to my blessed mother desiring his company at Newton for that
necessity: Who accordingly came with Mr Browne; & divers
others; with whom & my dear husband we did receive the
pledge I hope of our Salvation. in that Supper of the Lord.

Through which means I was much comforted; helped, inlive-
-ned, & quickened; from that black veil of unbelief: which cloud
ed my hopes of Eternal Salvation. This most Excellent &
spiritual mercy, was not the least; but greatest I apprehen
ded to receive from God; far surpassing all temporals. as
Eternity does this finite beings of ours; Oh that my heart
would break in pieces; at the Joyful remembrance of his re-
-neweing grace favour & mercy wherein God was pleased to be
come my reconciled God in & through my dear Redeemers
bloodshed upon the Cross. And that my soul might for Ever
sing unto him Hallelujahs of praise in heaven; with Angels &
archangels; & all the Host of heaven. I here prostrate my
Soul before the Throne of grace: which hath showed me his poor
weak handmaid such hopes, such mercies, spiritual, &
opportunities of making my Calling & Election sure. And
he will for his free grace sake fulfil in me the full perfection of
Glory with him. to be hold y holy Trinity with Joy & admiration. &
doe his will perfectly; which is impossible on earth, for my weak
humaine frailties & imperfections; O Lord free me from this
body of corruption: that I might serve thee in holiness, all my
days; Amen.

div.head:
Mr Colvills Settlement of Mr Thorntons Estate: 166X
1662.
div.p:
After I had received this great mercy from God; &
satisfaction to my poor drooping Soul in the Perticipati-on
of the Lords Supper, as I mentioned; having endeavoured
to doe it in the best manner & measure of faith. repentance
& Charity prepared my self to meet my Saviour therein
laying down my spiritual wants before him. & craving
his Graces to be fulfilled in me; I found a Rich supply
according to the power of his word that those that ever came un
to him he would in no wise cast off.

so that through these testimonies (most Precious) I was the
better assisted to prepare; & be in readiness when my
God should call for me out of this Miserable world.
And that with a great deal of contentedness; & free Resig-
nation of my will to his divine pleasure.

And in the second place I counted it my duty to desire
the conscionable settlement of our temporal Estate, for our
Children; & Family according to Gods command to good
Esikiah
[word] I.e., Hezekiah. to set his house in order.

This concernment of my Children, for their future
Provision; both in respect of what was given me by the
goodness of my Dear Mother to dispose of at my death.
amongst my Children. As also to be a means to have
a firm Settlement of Mr Thorntons Estate according to
his Articles of Marriage drawn betwixt my mother & him
-selfe before marriage; which yet had not bin done so clearly
in the first Deeds, but so in favour of Mr T. that it would
not only breed scruples; but were directly contrary to the said
Articles leaving Power for him to disinherit my Children
This was neither known to nor mistrusted by my dear mot.
nor to my self; but in my late sickness; when a friend did
look on the said writings found them so: & made it appear
to Mr Thornton: which indeed he was then willing to correct
but it was deferred till this time.

And now being more sensible of what Evil might succeed if
this business were not firmly don: & that I had none of my
201
own Relations near: Also being in a great strait what
to doe & doe right to all Parties: fearing the drawing on of
my time before this was finished. & then it might fall out
in the worst for the disadvantage of my Poor Children: have
ing then but two Daughters living; Also I found that the
several engagements for Debts of others,
had taken away for their satisfaction, with other Chargesin building the house
All my English Portion of 1500l that Estate of Burne Parke
of one hundred pound; per Annum settled before marriage on
my younger Children for maintenance & Portions: it was
sold for this Debts; And also with the disbursement of the
sum of 300l I laid out for the house since my mothers death
to assist him with out of my own money for my Children.
I had bin further instrumental to his assistance, in giving
Leave that my 1000l to be received out of Ireland which was
settled on me & my Children by bond before marriage: should
go to the satisfaction of his brothers & sisters Portions which
was not yet discharged: & Debts so that having thus disposed of
all my own Portion from my self & Children; together
with their Estate for their Provisions. I thought my
self obliged in Conscience to desire Mr Thornton should
settle the remainder of his Real Estate upon his Heir: if
God should give him one by me; & for the subsistence of
his younger Children, in lieu of my fortune: which was
from my father: 2500l from my mother; in Land;
Monies; Plate: goods to the value of one thousand Pounds
besides the advantage of 8 years table: with our selves: Child
& servants stood in 200l per Annum.

upon the serious consideration of these things: I was in
much deliberation who I should get to doe this charita
-ble office for us: And upon my Addresses to the Lord my
God for direction & other pertinent Petitions my Cosen
Covill first presented my thoughts: who by Mr Thornton
& my self was sent for to Newton; where he made such
A settlement of his Estate: as was necessary, & satisfactory
to my husband & my self: with prudence & Equity.
as wee both did approve of & with Mr Thorntons full consent &
desire therein.

Albeit there wanted not some, who guided, by self
interest repined by any thing which tended to the support
of Mr Thornton & his Children: Especially by me because I was
not of their faction as I was told. Although I may, & doe appeal to
themselves; whether I have not laid out my self &
fortune to secure all Peoples Just rights from us if it were
never so prejudicial to my own interest. And so may
hope for a blessing according to my good conscience & in-
tegerity; who having given to my husbands & friends use; & for
his debts which I could no way be capable of in contracting
from my own Children, that which should be for there provision;
so that had I not endeavoured some satisfaction; for those
whom God had given me; I had been unworthy to have
borne the name of a mother; leaving them in such an un-
settled Estate & sad condition; yea even altogether un-
provided for in this world: showing my self one of St Paul's
Infidels: He that provideth not for them of his own house
hath denied the faith & is worse then an Infidel;

so then let not others uncharitable displeasure: blame
what was don in this kind; since my dear husband was
pleased to show his love & affection to his faithful wife
& Children; in answer to the (Noble fortune as he called it
that he had with me; whose trouble only, was that his burdens
was so great that he was compelled to lessen his Estate in-
part to free the rest; Nor could he leave more for his yon-
ger children's Maintenance, & Education, & Portions, then
Laistrop; which was about 100l per. Annum And this did
not satisfy those peoples, humours, as I was told
by my dear husband; because it was not Charged
with debts first to precede my Children's Provision
Albeit we had by mutual consent set over A debt
from Sr Christopher wand. out of Ireland for 7. years of
200l per Annum: which was by agreement to satisfy for
my 1000l Portion: & the Debt which my husband had paid
to nettelton. Also the 1000l which was Left of the sale of
203
Burne Parke was laid out in a Rent Charge out of Mr
Laurance Sayers Land of 80l per Annum. This was deput
ed for the Debts: All which did amount to the sum of 3000l
nor did the Debts of Mr Thornton amount to that sum by
600l Nevertheless by the sequel of all it did appear; that
This just & honest action of ours did exasperate such-
with out a cause: who had desires that Laistrop so well as
the Rest of all his Personal Estate should go for security
Collateral to the rest: And by that means nothing should
be left at certain for my poor younger Children.

The case seemed very hard to me: And made me endeavour
the more earnestly to prosecute this settlement; which yet I
obtained, with a grand difficulty by reason of these obsta
-cles; but at last prevailed to have it don with out the said
contingency; nor did I intend to Alter the same with out
great cause. which I hoped in God would not be; because there
was so great a sum left for his debts, & was made be-
lieve it could not be cut of the Entail with out my consent
but it proved afterward the contrary, to my great grief
& almost my utter Ruin; & my Children's.

There was left only Newton which was my Jointure settled
so on my heir. that it could not be cut off with out my consent
in passing a fine: nor was the Rents ever more clear then
seven score paid a year. of it.

And now I heartily thank my gracious God who gave me
opportunity to get this don; for the satisfaction of my
conscience & the relief of my Children; blessed be his name
that did not take me out of this Life before: least by some
means they might have bin disappointed. and I leave
both my husband & Children, all in the wise & gracious
disposition of the Great God, humbly craving his blessing
upon them all for Christs sake Amen.

div.head:
Upon my deliverance, of my son Robert Thornton
my 7th Child: borne at Easte Newton: the first child
that was borne in the new house: Sept. 19th 1662
div.p:
Almighty God; The wise disposer of all good things
both in Heaven & Earth. Who seest what & how much
of the comforts of this mortal Life is conveniently fit for
us to enjoy in this Earth; hath at length had pity
on my afflictions & gave me such a mercy & dear
in-
joyment to my self & husband; after all his & mine
several troubles & losses of Sons: As I could not hope
for or Expect:

Making me a Joyful Mother of a sweet Son. borne at
full time; after 5 great trials, & hazards of miscarige
-s when I was with him; the one of sickness;
