O Death I will be thy Death. O Grave I will be thy
Victory. thanks be to God: through our Lord Jesus Christ.

div.head: An inducement to Love Heaven
div.l: Leave me o love, which Reachest but to dust.
And thou my mind aspire to higher things
Grow rich in grace, which never taketh Rust:
What ever fades, but fading pleasure brings.
Draw in thy beams, and humble all thy might.
To that Sweet yoke, where lasting freedoms be.
Which breaks the Clouds, and opens forth the light
That doth both shine, and gives us sight to see.
O take fast hold, let that light by thy guide
In this small course, which birth draws out to death
And think how Evil become'th him to slide,
Who seeketh heaven & comes of heavenly breath.
Then farewell world, thy uttermost I See.
Eternal love maintain thy life in me.

div.head: A farewell to the World.
div.l: Farewell the gilded follies, pleasing troubles.
Farewell the hon.red ragges the Crystal bubbles
Fame's but a hollow Echo, Gold poor Clay.
Honour the darling but of one short day.
Beauties chief Idol, but a damask skin
State, but a golden Prison to live in.
To vex free minds, embroidered trains
And goodly Pageants, proudly Swelling veins
And blood allied to Greatness, is but lone,
Inherited, not purchased not our own.
Fame, Riches, Hon.or, Beauty, State, Trains, Birth
Are but the fading Pleasures of the Earth.
I would be Rich, but see man too unkind,
Digs in the Bowels of the Richest Mine.
I would be great, but yet the Sun doth still.
Level his beams against the rising hill.
I would be fair, but see the Champion Proud
The worlds fair Eye, oft setting in a Cloud.
I would be wise, but that the Fox I see
Suspected guilty, when the Fox is free
I would be Poor, but see the humble grass
Trampled upon, by each unworthy Ass.
Rich hated; Wise suspected; scorned if poor,
Great feared; fair tempted; high still envied more.
Would the world then adopt me for her Heir.
Would Beauties Queen entitle me the fair.
Fame speak me hon.nrs minion, & could I.
With Indian Angels, & a speaking Eye.
Command bare heads; bowed knees strike Justice Dumb
As well as blind & lame, & give a Tongue.
To stones by Epitaphs; be called great Master,
In the last lines of every Poetaster:
Could I be more then any man that lives.
Great, Wise, Rich, Fair, All in Superlatives.
Yet I these favours would more free Resign
Then ever fortune would have had them mine.
I count one minute of my holy Leisure
Beyond the mirth of all this Earthly Pleasure.
Welcome Pure thoughts, welcome my saddest Groves
These are my guests; this is the Joys I love.
The winged People of the Skies shall Sing,
Me Anthems by my Sellers gentle Spring.
A Prayer Book shall be my looking glass
Wherein I will adorn Sweet Virtue's Face.
Here dwells no heartless loves no pale faced fear
No short Joys purchased with Eternal tears
Here will I sit & sigh my weak youths folly
And learn to affect an holy Melancholy.
And if contentment be a Stranger then.
He ne'er look for ill butt in Heaven again.
Ah foolish, faithless, fickle world where in.
Each motion is a vice, and every act a Sin.
finis.

div.head: My faithful Soul's wish.
div.l: Oh; had I of his love but Part,
That chosen was, by Gods own heart.
That Princely Prophet David he,
Whom in the word of truth I see.
The King of Heaven so dearly loved,
As mercy beyond measure proved:
Then should I neither Giant fear,
Nor Lyon that my Soul would tear.
Nor the Philistines, nor such friends.
As never, were true Christians friends.
No passions should my Spirit vex
Nor sorrow so my mind perplex.
But I should still all glory give
Unto my God by whom I live.
And to the Glory of his Name
Through out the world divulge the same.
My walk should be but in his ways
My talk but only in his Praise.
My Life a death, but in his love.
My death a life for him to prove.
My care to keep a Conscience clean.
My will from vain thoughts to wane.
My pain, and pleasure, travail, ease.
My God thus in all things to please
Nor Earth, nor Heaven should me move,
But still my Lord should be my love
If I am sick he is my health.
If I am poor. he is my wealth,
If I am weak, he is my strength,
If dead, he is my Life at length.
If scorned, he only is my Grace;
If banished, he my Resting place.
If wronged, he only is my Right.
If sad, he, is my Joy, & Soul's delight;
In Sum and all, All only he;
Should be all, above All to me.
His hand should wipe away my Tears,
His favour free me from all fears,
His mercy pardon all my Sin,
His Grace my life anew begin.
His love my light to Heaven should be
His Glory thus to comfort me;
And as t'is writ such honour shall.
Even unto all his Saints befall.
finis.

div.head: Upon Rash Censorers
div.l: Judge not that field; because ti's Stubble,
Nor her that's poor, and full of trouble
Though t'one look bare the other thin.
Judge not, their Treasure, lies within.

div.head:
A Recollection of Memorable accidents, &
Passages. forgotten to be Entered into my Book.

div.note:
this must be placed In the first Place Page 8th before the
The measels in 1629
div.head:
At Kirklington 1629
[+]
Upon my deliverance from death by a fall.
when I was 3 years old. when I cut a great wound in my forehead of above an Inch long
div.p:
My Father, & mother, living at Kirklington;
where I was borne; & my brother Christopher also
The same maid servant attended upon him, and was
his dry nurse, (Sara Tomlinson) which kept me. after I
was weaned; being like wise both nursed by one
wet nurse. tho upon having a fresh milk, she had
a Child betwixt the nursing my brother & my self
And having bin very good & careful of the first Child
my Parents saw it fit she should nurse the 2d Child too.
discharging the duty so well to me. I heard it observed that
I was both a strong & healthful child all a long. never
having had either the Rickets or any other disease.
for which I most humbly & heartily give thanks to the
God of my salvation, which still had his gracious Eye,
of Providence over me both at my birth, when my
dear mother brought me forth in great Peril of her
life she being weak. upon the birth of all her Children
having had seven in all: 4 Sons & 3 Daughters.
Yet the Lord gave me a Sound healthful body straight
Limbs & of a reasonable understanding Praised be his
glorious name for ever.

Yet has his goodness bin more extended to me in this
& all other preservation That I might not forget his
mercies for ever. And that hath many ways of the extent of
of his favours to young Infants in there deliverances
from death & destruction in this world besides that of sicke'n
esses & weakness of body. for if his divine Providence did
not send his Angels to keep & guard little Children They
could not continue not be preserved from all evil Actident-ts
287
And casualties, incident to That feeble and weak
Estate of Infants & Childhoods:

For although there innocency be not capable of offending
others. yet that Innocency & harmlessness is not able to
defend them from Injurious dealings from evil
Persons. neglects, & Brutishness of nurses & careless
ness of others. not to mention those infinite hazards
of over laying; & badness of there food & evil milk
Added to the dreadful malice of Satan who doth
by all means Endeavour to destroy man Kind.
sets on work all his engines against us by more
designs then we can see or be capable to understand
There fore am I for ever bound to bless the Eternal
name of God who hath sent his guardian
Angel to watch over me and mine for my good &
Preservation. ever since I was borne. The number
of his miraculous deliverances are past finding out
yet will I call to mind what I can that he might receive
receav the Glory of. All. There was now a most great
preservation to me when I was but a little Child &
was following my maid Sara watts Tomlinson
who cared
[word] I.e., carried. my brother Christopher in her Arms
& I took hold of her Cote. my weak hand being
but about 3 years old could not go so fast after her
but my feet stumbled against the Threshold. &
fell upon the corner stone of the hearth in the
Chamber called the Passage chamber which leads to
my dear mothers Chamber. At which time I
broke the Scull of my fore head in the very top.
against the said Rowbe. so grievously about an Inch
long insomuch that the skin of the brain was
seen & in great danger of death being like to
have bleed to death it being so desperate a
wound. But by the Providence of God & my dear
mothers skill & care of me she did make a
perfect Cure only a great scar still remains & will
never be gon. to putt me in fresh mind of my great
obligation to &, deliverance, of Almighty God for my
Life.

How hath my forget full soul let this mercy
slip out of mind & not remembered to give the Lord his
praises due to his name. But now o my soul return
Thy solemn thanks, & praises to this great & gracious
God who hath had mercy and compassion both on thee
when thou wast a poor weak Infant. & brought
Thee to these years through infinite more dangers.
To the Lord my God therefore doe I pour out my Soul
in humble gratitude for this great preservation in the
beginning of my days. beseeching him to accept of me now
his handmaid. both to serve him & praise him for ever.
And with all my might doe I sing praises to his glorious
name, who hath had the same Pity, & compassion both
as a tender & dear Parent & Guardian. O let thy
Providence still go along with me all my days. &
that thy Angel Guardians may defend me with thy
shield to preserve me from Precipice. or falls. or dislocation
incident to this life. who now grows in my later Age
even almost a Child, in strength leave me not
nor forsake me. who has non to depend on but thee the
God of mercies. who hath made & upheld me ever
since I was borne. bring me into that state of Innocency
of Soul by a conversion, truly into the state of Grace.
That I may freely bear thy trials & believe thy Promise
That through them I may at the last be conducted into
the land of Eternal Rest. there to sing & praise thy
holy glorious name & holy Trinity for ever & ever.
Amen. & Amen.

div.head:
A great deliverance from drowning in Ireland
by a fall out of the coach as my mother & us Ch.
was going to Killdare.
October: 6th 1636. Riding by the coach
div.p:
As my dear mother (my hon.red Father) my self &
brothers, George, Christopher, & John. was going in the
Coach to see Kildare after my father bought it there
was a narrow place we were to pass by a River Sid.
289
Joseph Browning being the coach man a very
[word] SiC ??? for very.
careful man yet could not avoy
[word] SiC ??? for avoid? that way being
none other to take but for seeing the apparent
danger of falling, (by providence he rather chose to
throw the Coach on the right hand towards the dry
land Upon a bank side which did hurt some of us
Then to fall on the left hand there being a great
River close by the Coach, which if we had gon down
on that side it had bin impossible we could have
bin Saved any of us, but all in the Coach & horse
had bin utterly lost & Perished in that deep River
my father did ride on horse back but by reason
of the narrow way could not make any Assistance
nor his men to help us in that danger. but was
much affriged
[word] SiC ??? for affrighted? at that sudden accident.

But when he saw the Coach fell from the River
did much rejoice, & glorified God with us for all
Preservation: Glory be the holy name of our
great & gracious God for ever. for all our safeties
& in giving us our lives with my dear mother: we
was not worthy of thes infinite deliverance nor
all thy mercies o Lord to us. But praised by
Thy great name most high. who had pity on me
Thy poor Creature & young Child.

O Lord my God blessed be thy majesty for this
great deliverance & saving me from this death oh
let me live to Praise thy name for ever & accept
of my Soul & service All my days for Jesus Christ
his Sake Amen. Amen.

div.head:
A great deliverance from a 2d fall
at Sr Robert Merideths in Dublin
in Ireland 1637.
div.p:
My Lady Anne Wentworth. & Lady Arbella with
Cozen Anne Hutton, Mrs Anne Loftus & my self
being invited to dinner to Sir Robt. merideths to dine
The ladies using the custom to swing by the Arms
for recreation & being good to exercise the body
of Children in growing, it was ordered by my Lady
Straford they should doe it moderately & found good in
it: so that they used to swing each other gently to that
Purpose. They would make me being a young girl
doe the same with them & I did so & could hold very
well by the Arms as they did & had never got no hurt
by it. I bless god but found it did me good &

Butt at this time very unfortunately some of the
young Ladies bid one of the Pages (Called don de Lan.)
a french boy That he should swing me being strong
[word] I.e., strong[er]
then they & they weary with Play. Butt I cried out
desiring them not to bid him but could not get off so
soon from him & deliver my self from danger before
he had came to me. He immediately Pushed
me so violently from him with all his force as I was
swinging by my Arms. That I was not able to hold
my hands on the swing. So that he throwed me down
me downe upon the chamber Boards. I fell down upon
my face fell to the ground & light with such a violent
force with all my weight on my Chin Bone upward
That both thee chin & chapp bones was almost broke
asunder & putt the bone out of its Place. And did
291
Raise a great Lump as big as an Egg under
my Chin & throat, which suddenly astonished me
and took a way my breath in so much as I was
nigh death, they thought I had bin dead:
for a good space of time. till by the great mercy
& Power of my gracious God I came to my self
again upon the use of good means The whole
house was concerned for my distress & this sad accident
butt much more my dear Lady Anne that her Page should
doe so great a mischief to me:

At length it pleased God I came to my Self again
but a long time ere I knew any body being in great
pain and extremity. Being kept there till night
before I could be able to go home.

But coming home to my dear mother she was
surprised to see that sad misfortune befallen to me
Tho bless God Almighty she applied such good means
as did recruit me after a long time being so bad.

But oh what great cause have I to cast my
self down at thee feet of the great & dreadful
Lord God who am but dust & Ashes. made by his
Power & preserved by his Providence ever since I was
borne & has delivered me this time so wonderfully
from a sudden & violent death even
[word] SiC ??? i.e., even. when I was
in a childish sport or play. or what ever it was thou O
Lord my God which did deliver me both now & at all
times of my life therefore will I give all thanks &
praise for ever with my Soul and body & spirit for ever
Although I was not willing to swing at this time yet
did thou deliver me Lord make me thankful for ever
& that I may never forget this mercy to glorify thy
great name And that I may still be preserved to live
to thy Glory in life & conversation for Jesus Christ his
sake to whom be praise for Ever more Amen & Amen.

div.head:
A dreadful fire in the Castle of Dublin.
1638.
div.p:
About 3 years before my noble Lord of Straford
his death there happened a great and dreadful
fire in the Castell of Dublin, which did go nigh to
have burned it down & destroyed it to the ground
had it not bin Prevented by Providence:

There being some up in the the other part of the Court
where Sir George Ratclifs lodging was. which saw it
it & cried out for help being at the dead time of
the night it was very Terrible to be hold. It began
upon the account of a maid servant setting a
dust basket of charcoal Embers taken out of the
Chapel Chamber & carelessly set under the Stairs
that went up to the Store house that night which kindled
of it self, burned down stairs & that Room called
the Chapel Chamber above the Chapel. which was most
Richly furnished with black velvet embroidered
with flowers of Silke-worke in Ten stitch all fruit Trees
and flours & slips embroidered with gold twist &
It burned the stately Chapel built by my Lord & my
Lady's Lodging. with the young Ladies. But by the
great mercies of God prevented there destruction &
was awakened by the flame appeared on the other side of the
Court. & great help was made with speed to preserve
my Lady & the rest which was brought out of bed in blanks
[word] I.e., blankets? As in Anselment?
Blessed be the Great God of Heaven for these deliverances
and all his glorious Providence to the Family & all the
Kingdom in them & to my father & his family Amen. Amen

Dec. 10 1640. My brother Christopher Wand.
being in the Church called Christs Church in
Dublin hearing the great & dreadful cry that
the Irish made at my dear fathers Funeral
was so frighted that he fell into the most grievous
fits of the Spleen which much tormented him for many
years after & had like to have taken his life away
butt blessed be the gracious God by my dear mother
excellent cares. cost, & pains he was cured & became
a very strong man. & lived to be the Father of that Fam
of which he was descended & was my beloved brother
living to the Age of 61 years & died at London
feb. 23d 1686.
buried at Kirklington by his Antien
ters

div.head:
Of the making; & Preservation of my dear
& hon.red Fathers Last will & Testament in
Ireland in the Rebellion. & by what Providence
Date Octo 2
1640
it was found out & our destruction
thereby Prevented:
div.p:
This my dear fathers will was dated october 2d 1640
Proved, & left on the file by Coz. william wandesford
an Executor. remained on the file for several years
Till the year 1647. when my brother George wandesf
went into Ireland to get a true copy of it & not having
money to discharge it The sad will was laid by in a Chest
by the Clarke who had writ it out & thes was sececd
[word] I.e., secured? for several
year of the sarre after my brother George died & non knew
what became of it.

Upon which great fact & troubles arose for the want of it
by Sir John Lowths bad counsel to my brothr Ch. wand. who
marred his daughter & would have come into the Estate by the
Entail.

But all
[word] I.e., 'att' ??? no tht eonly time she's forgotten to cross her t's. last by the Providence of the great God of heaven this
said will was discovd & produced in the year 1653 which did
put an end of all the Troubles: This is fully related in my 2d Book

div.head:
A Grate full Remembrance of my being preserved
from the fury of the wars in the time of the scots being
over the Poor Country in there madness against
us when I was at Hipswell with my dear mother
in 1643, 1644 &
div.p:
In this time after the Battle of Hessom moore
when the blessed
[word] Sic ??? i.e., blessed. King Charles had by Treachery lost
the field, & his two Generals, Prince Rupert &
Lord of new Castle exposed all the brave white cots
foot that stood the last man till they were murdered
& destroyed. & that my poore brother G. wand. was
forced to fly to hide himself at Kirklington. &
brought my brother Christop. behind him after which time
we got to hipswell & lived as quietly as we could for
the madness of the Scots
[word] SiC ??? for Scotts. who quartered all the County
ouer & insulted over this Poor Country, & English.

my dear mother was much grieved to be abued
[word] I.e., abused.
by them in quartering them at her own house. yet could not
Possibly excuse her self Totally from their men & horses.
Tho she paid double Pay & was at 01-6 a part
where
others at 09. only in a month.

She kept of the quartering Captain & commanders
& would never yield to have them. At length there
came one Capt. Inness. which was over
[word] I.e., over [commander] that troop we had
in Town. & he coming on a surprise into the house
I could not hide my self from them as I used to doe.
But coming boldly into my mother's Chamber where I
was with her. he began to be much more ernest and
violent to have staid in the house & said he would stay in
his quarters but we so ended the matter that we got him out by
all the fair mean could be to got quit of him who was so
vile a bloody looked man that I trembled all the time he was
295
In the house. I calling to mind with dread that he was so
infinite
[word] I.e., infinite. like in Person my Lord macguire the great Rebell
in Ireland was in a great Consternation
[word] I.e, consternation. for fear of him.

After which time this man impudently told my
Aunt norton that he would give all he was worth if
she could procure me to be his wife & offered 3 or 4000l
& Lord of Adare should come to speak for him. She said it
was all in vain He must not presume to look that way
for I was not to be obtained.
[word] I.e., obtained. And she was sure he might
not have any incoragnt
[word] I.e., encouragment. for I was resold not to mary.
& put him of the best she could. but writ me private
word that my Lord of Adare & he would come to speak
to me, & my mother about it, & willed me to get out of
his way. It was not to further that desire in me who did
perfectly hate him & them all like a Todd in such a kind

And immediately acquainted my dear mother which was
supised
[word] I.e., surprised. & troubled for she feared they would burn her
house, & destroy all: wished me to go whither I would
to secure my self: & I did so forth with run into the
Town, & hid my self privately in great fear & a fright
with a good old woman of her Tenants. where I bless
God I continued safely Till the visit. was over &
at night came home.

we was all joyful to escape so. for my d. M
was forced to give them the best treat she could & said.
indeed she did not know where I was. & sent out
fewe a little to seek me but I was safe from them

After which time this villain Captain did study
to be revenged of my d. M. & threatened cruelly what
he would doe to her, because
[word] I.e., because. she hid me Tho that was not
true for I hid my self. And about the time that the scots
was to march into Scottland being too long here on us
when my mother paid offtr 25l & 30l a month to them.

This Scott in a boasting manner sent for his Pay & she
sent all she ought to him which he would not take from
her, but demanded double money, which she would nor
could not do, so one sunday morning he brought the
company & Threatened to break the house & doors.
& was most vile, & Cruel in his oaths & swearing
[word] SiC ??? i.e., swearing.
against her & me; And went to drive all her goods
in her ground having this delicate Cattle of her
own breed. I went up to the Leader to see whether he did
drive them a way & he looked up & thought it had been
my d. m. Cursed me bitterly & wished the Deal blow
me blind & into the Air. & I had bin a thorne in his
heel. but he would be a Thorne in my side. & drved the
Cattle a way to Richmd where Generall Lecsley was.

So my dear mother was forced to Take the Pay he
was to have & carried it to the General that laid at my
Aunt nortons & acquainted him how that Captain had
abused her & wronged her. which by mercy of God to
her, This G. Leceley did take notice of & took her
money, & bid her not trouble her self for he would
make him take it or punish him for his Rudeness.
he said more did Innis That if ever
[word] SiC for 'ever'. any of his
Country men came into England. They would burn
her & me & all she had. But yet she served that God
which did deliver us out of the Irish Rebellion & all the
Blood shed in England, till this time And did now deler
her and my self & all we had from him:

This was a great deliverance,
[word] I.e., deliverance. at last & Joined with my
own single deliverance from this Beast. from being
destroyed & deflowered by him. for which I have reason to praise
the great & mighty God of Mercy to me.

There was one of his men that I had cured of his
hand being cut of it & lame. so that fellow did
me a signal return of gratitude for it. Thus
It was some times a refreshment to me after I
had sit up much with my dear weak mother in
her illness, or writing, of letters for her. That she did
bid me walk out to Cows with her maid to rest
my self so I used this some times. Butt this Captain
man who I curd came to me one day. Saying dear
Mrs I pray do not think much if I desire you for
God sake not to go out with the maids to Cows. I
said why. he said again he was bound to tell me.
That his Captain did curse & swear. That he
would watch for me & that very night he had desigd
[word] I.e., designed.
with a great many of his Comrades to catch me
at Cows & force me on horseback away with them
& God knows what End he would make of me. I sad I
hoped God would deliver me from all such wickedness
and so I gave the man many thanks who was So
Honest to prseve
[word] I.e., preserve. me from there Plots. rewarding him for
his pains, & did never go abroad out of the House.
again but ford
[word] I.e., forced. to keep like a Prisoner while they
was here. Blessing the great God of heaen
[word] I.e., heaven. who
did not suffer me to fall into the hands of those
wicked man nor into the hand of Sir Jerimy Smith
son who could never prevail by no means to
obtain me for his wife. & I was thus delivered also fm
such a force by the discovery of Tom Binkes.

Lord make me truly thankful for preservation of
me thy poor handmaid And make me live to thy Glory Am

div.head:
My deliverance from Drowning in the River at midlam
when I went to be a witness to my sister Danbys first
Francis Borne at Midlam Castle in the year 1644
div.p:
At that time Sir Thomas Danby was forced with my Sister
& Children to be in safety from the Parliament forces
he being for King Charles the first. to Midlam Castle
A garrison under my Lord Lofftus. There she was delivered
of her first Son Francis Danby. my sister having
got my Lord Lofftus, & my Lady H self with
annother Co.Branlen
for witness. I was forced to go over the River near
midlam called swaileUre which had some stoops set up for
guides & if one had raised the Caucy they had been
[word] I.e., been. erre-
-covrably lost. at that time I was very hearty & strong
& did venture to ride the same or else might have gon
back & rather then she should be disappointed did venture
over after my mo. servant who led the way but it
happened the River proved deeper then we expected it
& I kept up my horse as well as I could. from standly
[word] Cf Anselment n256 ??? 'obscure' transcribed by him as 'stand[ing]', i.e., hesitating.
& so bore up a long time. But when we were gon so
far that I could not turn back The River proved past
Riding & the bottom could not be come to by the poor
mare which was an excellent mare of my poore brother
G. wandesfords So I saw my self in such apparent danger
And begged of God to asset me & the poor Beast I rid on & to
be merciful to me & deliver me out of that death for J. Cht
his sake. And the poor mare drew up her fore feet & I
perceived she did swim. I gave her the Reins & took of
the short Reins of the breech & gave her the head with all the
help I could & clasped my hands about her maine did
freely commit myself to my God. to do what he pleased
[word] I.e., pleased. with me
And she did by mercy bear up her head & swimd out
aboue half a quarter of a mile across that dreadful River & by
gods great mercies brought me over
[word] I.e., 'over', variant of o'er. that River in Safety. which deliver
was so great & dread full that I can never forget to praise the god
299
And my great & gracious Lord God who had pity on me
at this time to spare me from this death & destruction
oh what shall I render to the great God of heaen who
has delivered me from Perishg by this water & caused this poor
creature to bring me out safe all glory be to my gracious
God of heaven by all the Power of men & Angels for ever.
o let me live to thy glory & serve thy majesty for Ever Amen.

A remembrance of a great deliverance I had
from drowning as I was going over the River
Swale to St nickolas to my Aunt Nortons. when
A flood came down on me, & Ralph J.anson.
in the year. 1646.

A very great deliverance of me as I was going over
the River at midlam when my Sistr Danby laid in of
one of her Sons called francis & was at midlam Castle
in the year 1644

A great deliverance of me from being destroyed
with a cannon Bullet at weschester being besieged
by Sir will.m Brewertons Army they shift into the Town
of weschester and as I was at my prayers in the Tent
with the window open the waft shut the casnt
[word] I.e., casement? & I fell don
on my knees & took breath from me. but bled
[word] I.e., blessed. be the Lord I
was delivered from death. at that time also to Praise his
holy name. For. Ever. 1647.

And was delivered from that siege also by miracles
of mercy & brought us Safe into our own Country York
shere.

A great deliverance from the violence of a
Rape from Jerimy Smithson. Sir
Ierimys Heughs
Son who had solicited me in marriage by
his father & uncle Smithson who would have
settled on him 200l a year if I would have
married him. but I would not, but avoided
his company because he was debauched. And he
hired some of his own company to have stolen me
away from cows. but Tom Binks discovered it I bless God

div.head:
Upon the reconciling of my two Brothers
George & Christopher Wandesford. March
21 9
on Easter Eve - before my bro. G was lost
1651
div.p:
Upon Easter day & had a full satisfaction of there true love & affection to each
other & ever After to his death for which I doe bless & praise the God of Heaven for ever
It was no small grief & trouble to me that
the wickedness of my Eldest brothers servant
by idle stories to my deare Brother George
against my poore brother Christ. had so
fare prevailed with him as to make a very
great breach in there friendship so that the younger
did Apprehend himself, much injured &
wronged there by to his brother George-
by them: & the other. Tho a very wise & under
standing Person; had bin highly incensed
at some lies which was told of his brother to
him, & by this means caused a very great
anger against each other; which proceeded to hy
& caused them to have such animosity as that
they neither could be satisfied to receive the
holy Sacrament:

But it pleased God to make me the happy
instrument to persuade, & entreat each of them
to such moderation & Charity, to ask each other
pardon (& God in the first place) for what had bin
amiss & to freely forgive one another & put any
all former disgusts or displeasure. & to be Cordially
reconciled for his sake who died for us. & with great
comfort I prevailed with them to receive this holy feast
of love to which we were to come & on the Eastrday. I bless
my God we did receive that holy Sacmt in Zeal & devotion.

head.l: Celestial fear, thy Sacred genius, brings
--------unto the Palace of the king of Kings-----------

lg.l: G race seamed to wait on nature setting forth
E ven in thy native sense the height of Worth
O h, that thy virtuous life does well express
R elegius care, thy mind did well address.
G ods word to fear, as thy blessed name may be
E ven but a type of what shines clear in thee.
W itt, Judgement, virtues learning, and the rest.
A tending true perfection chose thy Breast.
N ot hoping for a higher seat since their
D esert they found transcending all Compare.
I mmortall fame, Crowned thy so noble Parts
S ounding thy praises due to thy deserts.
F orceing even envy to confess as much
O r burst with malice not daring for to touch.
R enowne so rightly, placed as to thy Fame
D eath well may add, but can't impair the Same

div.l: Excuse my failings, since tis' real love.
Moved my weak pen so weighty a task to prove.
I must no more; nor truth could say no less
Virtue. & grace, did still thy breast possess.
Each muse so plied her Ore, in thee deer Soul
Ambitious, which should most in thee, Control.
Thy Faith, thy hope, thy Great Charity
In lively Colours, shined, bright in thee.
Although thy Cruel Enemies with hate:
Pursued thy Life, Religion, & thy EState
Yet Providence preserved them all, entire.
And filled thy breast with holy fire:
From that blessed Alter; which on the day before
Thou poured thy offerings out, him to adore.
And reconciled, thy self, to God; and Man.
Prepared for thy great change before it Came
What, tho thy death was sudden (to our Eyes).
Yet thou being ready (for that Lord) t'was no surpris
Thou, changed Earth, for Heaven, foes for friends
Then begin thy Joys that Never End:

But who can speak the Sorrows that
spread oppressed
Each Bleeding heart, & Eye and Breast.
at this sad object struck with horror Dumb,
To see thrice gallant Wansfords mare. mortum
ore Run its Banks. That Ancient River Swale
By this sad fortune, did a Curse Entail.
Not only on its Self, which now did fall
But on that noble family we Call.
In him. that Name was blessed by succession
Of Brave Heroic Persons in Possession.
See how it droops, & falls, & almost Dead
To see this dreadful Loss of this it's head.
Could all our Sighs, & groans, & tears.
Prevail, to Call thee back again; our fear
-would bee that non could keep thee here
The worst of Enemies did be-wail:
The loss of so much hon.or in him failed.
Since he was dead, the most of worth was gon
The Country did cry out; in him, t'was, Oh, Alone:
Oh what meant that Rash flood. by one wave to Throw
A ruin on its own fame. & us too;
So brave A vessel & so Richly Fraught.
That guilty River has to Ship-Rack Brought
As bankrupts all over Country; No man here
So unconcerned. but must let fall A Tear
Whilst the sad murmur of those Waters Call.
On Every Passenger to mourn his fall
What tho three days Submertion did entomb
All that was mortal of him in the Womb.
Of a Regardless Element we know.
Our great Redeemer, from the Parts-Below
Did by divine Power, on the third day Rise.
To open A nearer way to Paradise.
To that blessed Place my Soul desires to Fly
Lord then prepare me for it Ere I Dye.
Make me to Repent, to watch and Pray.
That so I may be Ready for that Day.
When thou shalt call this Soul from me.
With Joyful hope. I'll come to thee: Amen.
